questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents to the emergency department with the symptoms of urinary urgency, hesitancy, and the feeling of bladder fullness. The physician notes an enlarged prostate on digital rectal examination. Following a core needle biopsy, he is diagnosed with prostate cancer. Into which of the following structures do the prostatic ducts open?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostatic sinus

  • The prostatic urethra is 3–4cm long. Throughout its length, the posterior wall has a midline ridge called the urethral crest. On each side of the crest are shallow depressions called prostatic sinus, the floor of which is perforated by orifices of 15–20 prostatic ducts.
  • The prostate gland receives the ejaculatory duct, which opens into the prostatic urethra on the seminal colliculus/ verumontanum (a prominent elevation of the urethral crest) just lateral to the prostatic utricle, which is a small blind pouch.
  • The bulbourethral gland lies on the lateral side of the membranous urethra within the deep perineal pouch, but its duct opens into the bulbous portion of the spongy (penile) urethra.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Membranous part of the urethra

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the membranous part of the urethra.
  • The membranous part of the urethra lies outside the prostate.

Option B: Seminal colliculus  

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the seminal colliculus.
  • The seminal colliculus is just a prominent elevation of the urethral crest.

Option C: Spongy urethra

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the spongy urethra.
  • The spongy urethra lies outside the prostate and is the penile part of the urethra.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presented to you with ankle strain after playing a football match. You are evaluating the patient. In foot pronation, the axis of which two joints become parallel:-
questions.solution:
• Transverse tarsal (Midtarsal) joint is a collective term for the talonavicular (TN) part of the talocalcaneonavicular joint and the calcaneocuboid (CC) joint.
  • The two joints are separated anatomically but act together functionally.
  • During supination of foot, the soles face each other and there occurs inversion, whereas, in pronation, soles move outwards and is accompanied by eversion (TN and CC joint become parallel)

questions.text: A 29 year old male was brought to the Emergency after a road traffic accident. On physical examination, you notice that there is a loss of sensation of the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers. The likely nerve injured is/are:

choices.text: Median nerve plus ulnar nerve only
Median nerve plus radial nerve only

questions.solution:
Explanation: Loss of sensation of lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers is due to lesion of median and radial nerve.

  • Sensations on the palmar aspect of lateral 3 &1/2 fingers (including nail beds) are carried by median nerve.
  • Lateral 3 & 1/2 fingers (excluding nail beds) on the dorsum of hand are supplied by radial nerve.
  • Palmar and dorsal aspect of medial 1 &1/2 fingers (including nail beds) is supplied by ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with decreased mobility in his right arm. Physical examination reveals a winged right scapula and an inability to raise his right arm above the horizontal. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
• The serratus anterior, innervated by the long thoracic nerve, is responsible for stabilization of the scapula during abduction of the arm from 90 to 180 degrees.
  • When the long thoracic nerve is damaged, it is difficult to elevate the arm above the horizontal. This nerve arises from C5, 6, and 7.
  • Remember: a “winged scapula” is a classic clue for long thoracic nerve injury

questions.text: A 64-year-old female is brought with pain in neck and pain radiating down the arm. He has sensory loss over thumb and index finger with weakness of biceps and brachioradialis. What disc id affected?
questions.solution:
C6 Nerve Root compression

Sensory Deficit

Lateral forearm, thumb, and index finger

Motor Weakness

Biceps

Extensor Carpi raidalis longus and brevis

Reflex Change

Biceps

Brachioradialis

Indicative of C5 - C 6 herniation or other local pathological condition at that level.

C6 nerve weakness is indicative of C5/6 herniation as at this level C5 nerve root would have exited between C5 and C6 vertebrae. The C6 will exit between C6 and C7 vertebrae so it’s still within the spinal canal as the traversing nerve and hence amenable to damage.

Learning objective: Knowledge of dermatomes, myotomes and reflex arcs is an essential step in proper neurological assessment of any patient.

questions.text: You are a first-year surgery resident assisting in the Hepatectomy procedure with your senior resident. During the procedure, the portal vein is ligated. Which of the following vein unites to form a portal vein?

choices.text: Superior mesenteric vein & inferior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
Option A: Superior mesenteric vein & Splenic vein

Following are the main points regarding venous drainage of the gut:

  • The portal vein is formed by the union of the Superior mesenteric vein (SMV) and the splenic vein posterior to the neck of the pancreas.

  • The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein.

  • The hepatic portal vein pass posterior to the first part of the duodenum, in the free edge of the lesser omentum.

  • At the porta hepatis, it divides into right and left branches supplying the right and left lobes of the liver.

  • Within the sinusoids of the liver, hepatic portal blood and oxygenated blood from the hepatic artery mix together and come into contact with the hepatocytes, where metabolites such as products of digestion are exchanged.

  • Blood from the sinusoids empties into hepatic veins draining the liver and, in turn, drains into IVC, and blood is returned to the heart.

Option B: Superior mesenteric vein & inferior mesenteric vein

The superior mesenteric vein & inferior mesenteric vein do not join with each other 

  • The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein

Option C: Inferior mesenteric vein & Splenic vein

  • The inferior mesenteric vein & Splenic vein donot join with each other.

Option D: Inferior mesenteric vein & Hepatic vein

  • The Inferior mesenteric vein & Hepatic vein do not join with each other.

questions.text: Which of the following relations are true about the boundary of the marked foramen?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bile Duct Anteriorly

  • It is a true statement.
  • The marked foramen is Epiploic foramen.
  • The epiploic foramen is also called foramen epiploic or foramen of Winslow.
  • It is the passage of communication between the general cavity and the omental bursa.
  • Boundaries
    1. Anteriorly – Hepatic triad structures, including the Bile duct anteriorly, within the free margin of the lesser omentum.
    2. Posteriorly – Inferior Vena Cava
    3. Above (superiorly) – Caudate lobe of the liver.
    4. Below (inferiorly) – The first part of the duodenum

Option A: Hepatic artery posteriorly

  • The hepatic artery is a part of the hepatic triad, which makes the anterior boundary of the Epiploic foramen.

Option C: Portal Vein laterally

  • The portal vein is the posterior structure in the Hepatic triad.
  • The hepatic triad contains the hepatic artery, hepatic vein branches, and biliary ducts.
  • It forms the anterior boundary of the Epiploic foramen

 Option D: Inferior vena cava inferiorly

  • The inferior vena cava lies in the posterior abdominal wall and forms the Posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to the clinic with a several-year history of an enlarged scrotum developed after a bout of epididymitis. The scrotal skin is thickened and may exhibit ulcerations. Massive scrotal lymphedema is noticed. Lymphatic drainage of the testis is through which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pre and para-aortic nodes

  • Lymphatics and veins follow the arteries. Both lymphatics and arteries follow a lateral and anterior route to drain into a testis. So lymphatic drainage is pre and para-aortic lymph nodes.
  • The testis is the only one that does not drain the inguinal lymph nodes. Its lymphatics course along the route of the testicular vessels to reach the para-aortic lymph nodes at the level of the L2 vertebra
  • The septula testis' lymph capillaries are connected to the rete testis' lymph vessels and tunica albuginea.

 

 

Option A: External iliac nodes

  • The lymphatics of the testis do not drain in external iliac nodes.
  • It divided into medial, lateral and posterior grops
  • Medial group drains: urinary bladder, prostate menbranous part of uretha, cervix, upper part of vagina
  • Posterior group receives lymphatics from the internal iliac nodes via the obturator lymph nodes 
  • Lateral group drains lymph from superficial and deep inguinal nodes

Option B: Internal iliac nodes

  • The lymphatics of the testis do not drain in the internal iliac nodes.
  • It drains all pelvic viscera: The body of hte uterus, prostate gland, upper part of the vagina, seminal vesicles and the vas defens, the lower part of the ureters and the bladder.

Option D: Superficial inguinal node

  • It resides below the inguinal ligament 
  • divided into - the inferior, the superolateral and the superomedial nodes 
  • It drains: - The anal canal (below the pecitinate line) skin below the umbilicus, lower extremities, scrotum and vulva.
  • The lymphatics of the testis do not drain in the superficial inguinal node.

questions.text: Which of the following does not take part in forming the ovarian fossa?
questions.solution:
Option D: Round ligament of ovary

Ovarian fossa boundaries:

  • The ovary usually lies against the lateral wall of the pelvis in a depression called the ovarian fossa, bounded by the external iliac vessels above and behind the internal iliac vessels.
    • Anteriorly bounded by the obliterated umbilical artery.
    • Posteriorly bounded by the ureter and internal iliac artery.

Option A, B And C

  • The ovarian fossa is bounded anteriorly by the obliterated umbilical artery and Posteriorly bounded by the ureter and internal iliac artery.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old male presents to the physician complaining of progressive right upper quadrant pain, nausea, fever, and yellowing of the eyes and skin. He has no family history of serious illness. He has a 4-year history of intravenous heroin use and shares needles. His immunization history is unknown. He appears ill. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 109/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show:


	
		
			
			Prothrombin time
			
			
			37 sec (INR = 3.5)
			
		
		
			
			Total bilirubin
			
			
			5.6 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Direct
			
			
			1.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Aspartate aminotransferase
			
			
			1,560 U/L
			
		
		
			
			Alanine aminotransferase
			
			
			2,943 U/L
			
		
	


The structure involved in a patient's pathology is classified into:
questions.solution:
Option B: 8 segments

  • The liver is divided into 8 segments by DAV structures (bile duct, hepatic artery, portal vein)
  • This is a case of hepatitis B infection in which the patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, fever, and yellowing of the eyes and skin.
  • The patient is also a drug user, increasing the risk of hepatitis B infection.
  • The portal vein is the most important among them.
  • The portal vein separates the upper & lower segments

Option A: 6 segments

  • The liver is divided into 8 segments according to Couinaud’s classification.

Option C: 4 segments

  • The liver is divided into 8 segments according to Couinaud’s classification.

Option D: 10 segments

  • The liver is divided into 8 segments according to Couinaud’s classification.
  • So, according to this case, it is an incorrect option.

questions.text: In which of the followingphase of spermatogenesis does reduction in the chromosomal number to half the original number occur?
questions.solution:
Option B: Meiosis - I

  • Meiosis is a process where a single cell divides twice to produce four cells containing half the original amount of genetic information.
  • The first meiotic division is the reduction division, and each primary spermatocyte yields two secondary spermatocytes.
  • Each secondary spermatocyte contains 23 (Haploid) chromosomes consisting of two varieties, 22+X and 22+Y. Here 22 are autosomes, and X & Y are sex chromosomes.

Option A: During mitosis

  • Mitosis is a process in which the cell undergoes division to produce offspring.
  • In mitosis, daughter cells have the same chromosomes as the parent (diploid).
  • During the initial phase of spermatogenesis, the spermatogonia undergoes continuous mitosis division until the formation of the primary spermatocyte.

Option C: Meiosis - II

  • During spermatogenesis, the PGCs (Primordial germ cells or spermatogonia) undergo several mitotic divisions to form primary spermatocytes.
  • Primary spermatocyte after meiosis I →  two secondary spermatocytes (with 4 haploid chromosomes) → Meiosis II→ four haploid daughter cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the arrest of the primary oocyte in the diplotene stage of prophase-1?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oocyte maturation inhibitor

  • Oocyte maturation inhibitor acts by increasing cAMP, which leads to the arrest of the oocyte in the diplotene stage of prophase- I.
  • LH surge at puberty reduces cAMP, removing the oocyte from its arrested state.

Option B: Oocyte maturation stimulator

  • LH surge at puberty reduces cAMP, removing the oocyte from its arrested state.

Option C: Acetylcholine

  • It is the main neurotransmitter of the parasympathetic nervous system responsible for cholinergic actions.
  • Acetylcholine has no role in oogenesis.

Option D: Oestrogen

  • Any circulating estrogen comes from Theca interna cells
  • Local estrogen comes from Granulosa cells
  • On the 14th day, the ovum with surrounding Cumulus oophorus extruded from follicle collected by the fallopian tube fimbriae.
  • Oestrogen stimulates the development and maturation of ovarian follicles and also regulate FSH release.

questions.text: A 3-day-old boy who was born in the 32nd week of pregnancy suffers from respiratory distress syndrome. Doctors diagnose a heart murmur characteristic of an patent ductus arteriosus, a diagnosis that is confirmed by an echocardiogram. Which embryonic structure is involved in this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• PDA ( Patent ductus arteriosus ) is a condition in which, a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus connects Aorta and Pulmonary artery, allows blood to bypass the baby’s lungs before birth, fails to normally close after birth.
    • Ductus arteriosus is derived from the distal part of the left sixth aortic arch.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was brought to you for regular check up. The curvature of vertebral spine which can be seen in children of this age group is:
questions.solution:
A baby at 9 to 10 month develops a secondary curvature at lumbar region of vertebral spine. It occurs due to the baby trying to acquire sitting and standing posture at this particular age.

The vertebral column in adults has four curvatures that occur in the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral regions. The thoracic and sacral kyphoses are concave anteriorly. whereas the cervical and lumbar lordoses are concave posteriorly (i.e., convex anteriorly).

The thoracic and sacral kyphoses are primary curvatures that develop during the fetal period in relationship to the (flexed) fetal position. These primary curvatures are retained throughout life. The cervical and lumbar lordoses are secondary curvatures that result from extension from the flexed fetal position.

The cervical lordosis becomes evident when an infant begins to raise (extend) the head while prone and to hold the head erect while sitting (begins at the age of 2 months).

The lumbar lordosis becomes apparent when toddlers begin to assume the upright posture. standing and walking (begins at the age of 8 months).

questions.text: 8 year old female child following URTI developed maculopapular rash on the jaw spreading onto the trunk which cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation and tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option 1
  • Kawasaki disease (KD), also known as Kawasaki syndrome, is an acute febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. Clinical signs include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the whites of the eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.
  • Causes: No one knows what causes Kawasaki disease, but scientists don't believe the disease is contagious from person to person. A number of theories link the disease to bacteria, viruses or other environmental factors, but none has been proved. Certain genes may increase your child's susceptibility to Kawasaki disease.
Option 2

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Caused by Parvovirus B19
  • Children (fifth disease) - Slapped cheek rashes
  • Adults - Polyarthropathy
Option 3

1. Points in favor of Rubella are:

  • Maculopapular rash on the face spreading onto the trunk.
  • Rash is cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation.
  • Tender post-auricular and sub-occipital lymphadenopathy.

2. Rubella is a milder and more subtle disease than measles.

3. Postnatal rubella:

  • Virus excreted in oropharyngeal secretions and infection is acquired by inhalation.
  • Virus multiplies locally in upper respiratory tract & cervical lymph nodes ? viraemia, dissemination throughout the body.
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks, fine pink macules first appearing on the face and then spreading to involve trunk and limbs.
  • Enlargement of postauricular, suboccipital, posterior cervical lymph nodes.
  • Recovery within 3-4 days of appearance of rash.
  • Complications: Polyarthritis (adult women, thrombocytopenic purpura, encephalopathy, panencephalitis

4. Congenital rubella:

  • Virus can cross the placental barrier and infect the fetus.
  • Congenital anomalies/death of the fetus.
  • Congenital defects: deafness, cataract, glaucoma, microphthalmia, retinopathy, congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis), microcephaly, mental retardation, thrombocytopenic purpura, hepatosplenomegaly.
Option 4
  • MEASLES (RUBEOLA) VIRUS: Maculopapular dusky red rashes appear after four days of fever (i.e. at 14th day of infection).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with history of fever & headache for 2weeks with intermittent vomiting about three to four times per day. He had a history of repeated falls due to abnormal jerky movements of his whole body. The routine blood examinations revealed no abnormality. An MRI of the brain revealed findings consistent with SSPE. SSPE is associated with which of the following infections:
questions.solution:
Sub acute sclerosing pan-encephalitis

  • Also known as ‘dawson’s disease’, Dawson’s encephalitis
  • Rare complicatiuon of measles developing 7-10 year after measles infection
  • Frequency: 7 cases per million case of natural measles

questions.text: A 10 year-old girl presented with recent onset blurred vision, intermittent diplopia, 'black spots' in her visual field, and ataxia. After thorough evaluation & imaging, she was diagnosed with medulloblastoma. Which of the following chromosomal mutation is associated in such patients?
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma can be subdivided into the following 4 groups:

  • TheWNT type, characterized by mutations in the WNT signaling pathway, tends to occur in older children, has a classic medulloblastoma histology, and shows monosomy of chromosome 6 and nuclear expression of β-catenin. The prognosis is best in this subtype with 90% 5-year survival.
  • TheSHH type,characterized by mutations involving the sonic hedgehog signaling pathway, tends to occur in infants or young adults, tends to have a nodular desmoplastic histology and may haveMYCNamplification. The prognosis is intermediate between the WNT subtype and groups 3 and 4.
  • Group 3 medulloblastoma, often withMYCamplification and isochromosome 17 (i17q), tends to occur in infants and children, with a classic or large cell histology and the worst prognosis.
  • Group 4is characterized by an i17q cytogenetic alteration, classic or large cell histology, withoutMYCamplification, but sometimes withMYCNamplification. The prognosis in group 4 is intermediate. In general, isochromosome 17q signals a poor prognosis, and is restricted to groups 3 and 4.

questions.text: A 25 years old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. You were the assistant doctor with your senior for the delivery. After the successful delivery of the baby, your senior asks you what is the ‘first immunization’ of the baby?

choices.text: Handing over the baby to mother

questions.solution:
Option C: Colostrum

  • It is the most suitable food immediately after the birth of the baby; Regular milk comes 3-6 days after birth.
  • It is also known as ‘Beestings’, ‘First milk’, or ‘Immune Milk’.
  • Colostrum is high in carbohydrates, proteins, and antibodies, and low in fat.
  • It contains all five immunoglobulins found in all mammals, IgA (highest), IgD, IgE, IgG & IgM.
  • It is known as the ‘first immunization’ of newborns.

Option A: OPV

  • Oral Polio Vaccine / SABIN is a Bivalent vaccine (P1, P3 strain).
  • Dosage:
    • 1st dose is given immediately at birth or as soon as possible, then at 6 weeks followed by 10 and 14 weeks.
    • 1st booster: 16-24 months.
    • Another dose at 5 y along with DPT booster.

Option B: Handing over the baby to the mother

  • Handing over the baby to the mother is not the first immunization.

Option D: DPT + BCG

  • 1st dose of DPT is given 6 weeks after birth and 1st dose of BCG is given at the time of birth or as early as possible till one year of age.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl child was brought in with complaints of delayed development of growth milestones. She is also found to have decreased intellectual ability. Mental retardation is defined If IQ is below
questions.solution:
A child with IQ<70 is called mentally retarded -

The WHO classification of mental retardation is based on the concept of IQ and includes the following categories:

Category IQ
Mild 50-70
Moderate 35-49
Severe 20-34
Profound <20

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother due to excessive sleepiness for 1 week. It is associated with constipation for 2 weeks. He was delivered at term via normal vaginal delivery and had no medical check-ups afterwards. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant with periorbital puffiness, a large tongue, and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following tests will help diagnose the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: T4 and TSH assay

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism.

  • Hypothyroidism presents with constipation, pallor, edematous facies, open posterior fontanel, umbilical hernia, hypothermia, large tongue, rough, dry skin, hypotonia, and large abdomen.

  • Initial investigation of hypothyroidism includes TSH and T4 levels.

  • TSH level is increased, and T4 is decreased in primary hypothyroidism.

  • TSH level is reduced along with T4 levels in secondary hypothyroidism.

  • Other investigations include thyroid ultrasound and evaluation of radionuclide uptake.

  • Oral levothyroxine is the treatment for hypothyroidism.

Option A: Karyotyping

  • Karyotyping identifies chromosomal disorders such as trisomies and translocations.

  • Hypothyroidism is not a chromosomal disorder.

Option C: Rectal mucosal biopsy

  • A rectal mucosal biopsy is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease, which presents with constipation in the early neonatal period.

  • Rectal mucosal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

Option D: ACTH level

  • ACTH level is used to identify adrenal diseases such as Cushing’s syndrome and Addison’s disease.

  • It has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented with a 2 week history of swelling around the eyes & both legs and generalized body sweeling. After thoorogh evaluation, she was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. In such patients with nephrotic syndrome,edema is due to:
questions.solution:
Hypoalbuminemia

  • Albumin is the most abundant plasma protein and the size is just 69 kilodalton. So, it contributes the maximum to the plasma oncotic pressure.
  • If the concentration of albumin is lowered, fluid will no longer flow back into the intravascular compartment.
  • The resulting accumulation of fluid in the extravascular tissue spaces results in edema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: Based on the characteristic cytological findings (pictures shown below) in a 31 year old patient who underwent thyroid FNAC, identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Pap-stained liquid based cytology (LBC) of FNAC material showing nuclear grooving, pseudo-inclusions & Orphan Annie eye nuclei (ground glass clearing) → characteristic to papillary carcinoma of thyroid.
  • Other microscopic findings of papillary carcinoma:
    • Papillary formation with fibrovascular core
    • Psammoma bodies [concentrically calcified structures]

questions.text: A 23 years old male working in an iron factory visited the hospital for taking his TT dose. Injectable tetanus toxoid (TT) is an example of which of the following immunity?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Active immunity

  • The toxins produced by organisms such as Diptheria & Tetanus are detoxicated and used in the preparation for Vaccines (Toxoids).
  • These detoxified toxins when administered in the body can elicit an immune response resulting in antibody production & memory.
  • Antibodies are produced to neutralize the toxic moiety produced during infection by these organisms thus providing active immunization to the body.

Option B: Passive Immunity

  • Passive immunity is provided by the transfer of ready-made antibodies.
  • The host body does not produce its own Antibodies.

Option C: Native Immunity

  • Resistance to the infection from birth by its genetic or constitutional makeup.
  • Depends on
    • S: Species-specific
    • I: Individual specific
    • R: Race specific
  • Components
    • Phagocytes (monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils)
    • NK (natural Killer) cells
    • Alternate complement pathway
    • Acute Phase Proteins (CRP, MBP Serum amyloid protein)
    • Normal resident Flora
    • Inflammation, Fever
    • Skin & mucosal barrier

Option D: Innate immunity 

  • Innate immunity is present at birth.
  • Examples: Physical barrier, physiological barrier, cellular barrier, and inflammatory barrier.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is due to paternal disomy of chromosome 15?
questions.solution:
Discussing the options one by one:

A. Prader Willi syndrome: Uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15

B.Angelman syndrome:Uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15

C.Hydatidiform mole: Contains a normal number of diploid chromosomes, but they are all of paternalorigin.

The opposite situation occurs inovarian teratoma, with 46 chromosomes ofmaternalorigin.

Note thatHydatidiform mole & ovarian Teratoma are also due to uniparental disomy

D. Klinefelter’s syndrome: 47, XXY

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented with clinical features of Acute Myeloid Leukemia in peripheral blood smear. Initial investigation revealed leukostasis. Which organ is mainly affected in patients with Hyperleukocytosis - Leukostasis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lung

  • The Lungs and brain are the most commonly affected organs (44% and 36%, respectively) by hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome.
  • WBC counts more than 100,000/cu.mm lead to leukostasis plugging of the capillaries followed by endothelial damage to blood vessels.
  • The presence of dyspnea, tachypnea and respiratory distress indicate pulmonary leukostasis.
  • C.N.S. leukostasis presents with stupor, headache and dizziness.
  • The mortality occurs due to respiratory failure, intracranial haemorrhage and coma.
  • The low PO2 is due to increased consumption of oxygen by leucocytes.

Option A: Liver

  • Involvement of liver/G.I. in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 3%

Option B: Heart

  • Involvement of heart (myocardial infarction) in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 6%

Option C: Kidney

  • Involvement of kidneys in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 5%

questions.text: Which one of these four images is most likely to be a premalignant condition:
questions.solution:
A – Sub Mucous fibrosis

B – Geographic tongue

C – Candidiasis

D – Fordyce Spots

Sub Mucous fibrosis is a premalignant disorder characterised by inflammation and progressive fibrosis of the sub mucosal tissues inside the mouth.

Sub mucous fibrosis is often associated with chewing betel nuts.

It is due to chronic exposure to arecoline present in the betel nuts.

questions.text: A 64-year-old female presented to the emergency room with an episode of chest pain was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following statement is wrong about hypertrophic cardiomyopathy ?

choices.text: Systolic dysfunction arises due to mitral valve displacement
Adapted mitral valve result in anteriorly directed mitral regurgitation

questions.solution:
Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

  • Interventricular septum typically shows maximum hypertrophy
  • 30% cases show obstruction at rest while other 30% show when put on exercise.
  • Enlarged mitral valve pushesh against spetum and adaptation later may result in posteriorly directed mitral regurgitation
  • Harsh ejection systolic murmur is observed

questions.text: )A 27-year-old female was advised to get CT scan done. A radiographic image revealed a benign tumor as shown below. Identify the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The organ shown above where benign tumor is located, is liver

  • And the appearance of lesion is called as – central stellate scar

Central stellate scar is seen in

  1. Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)2)
  2. Fibrolamellar variant of Hepatocellular carcinoma
  3. Serous cystadenoma pancreas
  4. Renal oncocytoma

Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH )

  • Second most common benign tumour of liver
  • Young women
  • May be due to hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery
  • Characterised by central fibrous scar with radiating septa although no central scar is seen in approximately 15% of cases
  • Histology - Cords of benign appearing hepatocytes divided by multiple fibrous septa originating from a central scar
  • The central scar often contains a large artery that branches out into multiple smaller arteries in a spoke wheel pattern
  • Contains both hepatocytes and Kupffer cells
  • Associated with OCP use
  • Serum AFP levels are normal
  • Hepatic architecture is maintained
  • IOC– CECT (strong hypervascularity in the arterial phase with central nonenhancing scar)
  • Asymtomatic patients with typical radiologic features do not require treatment
  • Treatment for patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass or in case of diagnostic uncertainty - Resection

questions.text: A young male wanting to join the army is found to have mild jaundice during his medical fitness examinations. He comes to your clinic for further evaluation. The patient has no complaints except for passing dark-coloured urine even though he drinks plenty of water. Further testing revealed a mild increase in his serum total bilirubin levels, with an increase in both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels. His gallbladder can be visualized on oral cholecystography. A liver biopsy is taken, which shows no pigmentation. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rotor Syndrome

  • Rotor syndrome is a mixed hyperbilirubinemia characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice caused by chronic elevation of mostly conjugated (direct) bilirubin due to impaired hepatic storage.
  • It is usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with non-pruritic jaundice.
  • It is a benign disorder and does not require any treatment.
  • Rotor syndrome and Dubin Johnson Syndrome have plenty of similarities, and the difference are listed below:
  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson’s syndrome
Appearance of liver Normal appearance The liver has black pigmentation
Gall bladder visualization on oral cholecystography The gallbladder is usually visualized Gall bladder can't be visualized
Total urine coproporphyrin content High with <70% coproporphyrin I Normal with >80% coproporphyrin I

Option B: Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome

  • Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome and rotors syndrome share a lot of similarities.
  • Both are mixed hyperbilirubinemias.
  • The gallbladder is not visualized in Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome.
  • The liver also shows pigmentation in Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome.

Option C: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome

  • Crigler-Najjar Syndrome is characterized by an increase in unconjugated bilirubin levels only.

Option D: Gilbert Syndrome

  • Gilbert Syndrome is characterized by an increase in unconjugated bilirubin levels only.

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with High fever, sever unrelenting headache, sensitive to bright light and vomiting. On history taking revels that he had a tour with his classmates to Sahel region of West Africa he returned 3 days before. On the physical examination bradycardia, disorientation, papilledema, altered sensorium, neck stiffness, positive brudzinski's and kernig's sign are present. Physician is strongly doubt for pyogenic meningitis, which criteria is true about CSF finding in pyogenic meningitis.?
questions.solution:
Choice A is correct.

Pyogenic meningitis is inflammation of meninges then affects pia matter, arachnoid, sub arachnoid space and spinal cord. pyogenic meningitis is a acute onset disease with serious infection and associates marked inflammatory exudation, usually caused by bacterial infection. pyogenic meningitis maybe fatal if untreatend. Early symptoms of meningitis include: nausea and vomiting, fever ,headache and a stiff neck, muscle pain, sensitivity to light, confusion, cold hands or feet and mottled skin ,in some cases, a rash that does not fade under pressure csf finding shows increased protein and decreased sugar. Protein leaks into the subarachnoid space from the blood, resulting in markedly increased CSF protein.

Educational objective: Meningitis due to S. pneumoniae occurs most commonly in the very young and the very old Several strains of bacteria can cause acute bacterial meningitis, most commonly: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus). This bacterium is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in infants, young children and adults

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with complaints of right hypochondriac pain and fever. Physical examination revealed that the liver was palpable 5 cm below the right costal margin.He had no history of liver disease. After a thorogh evaluation & imaging, a provisional diagnosis of hepatoblastoma was made. All are true about the said diagnosis except:-

choices.text: Common in cirrhosis of liver due to HBV
Surgical resection is treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Two primary tumors of the liver are

HCC and hepatoblastoma

Hepatoblastoma is common in the pediatric age group and is associated with hereditary conditions like FAP,GARDNER SYNDROME, Beckwith WEIDMAN SYNDROME most common age group for hepatoblastoma is below 3 years of age

HCC

Age group 15-19 years

A/w acquired hepatitis b and c infection and congenital diseases like tyrosinemia, glycogen storage disease

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of dysphagia with episodic melena, muscle pain, rash, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and the examination of the hands reveals sclerodactyly, digital pits & ulceration. Initial investigations were done. Which of the following test can be for the diagnosis of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-nuclear antibody

  • This is a case of scleroderma in which the patient presents with complaints of dysphagia with frequent regurgitation, chronic Malena, myalgias, pruritus, progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips.
  • Examination findings of hands in involve sclerodactyly, digital pits &ulceration.
  • Anti-nuclear antibody- ANA is the screening method of choice for systemic rheumatic diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (S.L.E.), mixed connective tissue disease, Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma, CREST syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, polymyositis, and dermatomyositis.
  • These are a group of autoantibodies directed against different nuclear antigens such as D.N.A., R.N.A., histones, etc.
  • ANA can also be found in healthy sometimes.

Option B: U l- Ribonucleoprotein antibody

  • Anti-U1ribonucleo protein antibody is usually known to be a marker of Mixed connective tissue disease.
  • M.C.T.D. is an autoimmune disease with mixed symptoms of polymyositis, S.L.E., and scleroderma.

Option C: Anti- L.K.M antibody

  • The anti-liver-kidney microsomal antibody is found in chronic delta hepatitis.
  • It is sometimes also associated with chronic hepatitis due to the hepatitis C virus.

Option D: Anti- topoisomerase antibody

  • A.T.A. are autoantibodies that are directed against topoisomerase.
  • Mostly associated with scleroderma.
  • A.T.A. is usually not used for screening purposes in scleroderma

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic. She was concerned about the risk of breast cancer because her sister had recently been diagnosed with breast ductal carcinoma due to a BRCA mutation. Her family history of breast and ovarian cancer is significant. The physical examination was unremarkable. Her genetic testing results are also normal. Which factor may increase this patient's risk of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atypical epithelial hyperplasia 

  • Atypical epithelial hyperplasia (proliferative) increases carcinoma risk (4 – 5 times).
  • It is divided into two categories. 
    • Atypical ductal hyperplasia (5 - 7% of specimen biopsied for calcifications) 
    • Atypical lobular hyperplasia (5 % of biopsies and it is an incidental finding)
  • Both types of atypical hyperplasia have 
    • High estrogen receptor (ER) expression. 
    • Low rate of proliferation 
    • It can result in the loss of 16q and 17p gene regions or the gain of 1q. 
    • These mutations are similar to in situ carcinoma. 
    • Atypical lobular hyperplasia also causes E-cadherin loss, a feature of lobular carcinoma in situ. 
  • Other benign conditions are 
    • Sclerosing adenosis 
    • Fibrocystic change
    • Apocrine metaplasia 
    • Duct ectasia 
  • Non - proliferative diseases are 
    • Cysts
    • Fibrosis 
    • Adenosis 
  • It comprises a single epithelial layer and is primarily lined by normal luminal cells, which can undergo apocrine metaplasia. 

Option A: Sclerosing Adenosis 

  • It is a benign condition of the breast. 
  • It causes an increase in the number of acini and stromal fibrosis.
  • Due to the compression of the lumen by double strands of cells, a cord-like solid mass can be formed. 
  • On palpation, it resembles invasive carcinoma and should be investigated further with radiology and biopsy. 

Option C: Fibrocystic Changes 

  • Fibrosis occurs due to cyst rupture and material secretion into the stroma. 
  • Cysts form when lobules dilate, and then small cysts coalesce to form a larger one. 
  • It is a benign condition and does not increase the risk of carcinoma 

Option D: Apocrine metaplasia 

  • Apocrine metaplasia is a benign condition primarily affecting the lobule's inner lining. 
  • It is associated with fibrocystic changes as well as papilloma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with involuntary jerking, subcutaneous nodules and erythema marginatum due to acute rheumatic fever. The patient was ill with pharyngitis a month ago. There is no history of other neurological manifestations. On physical examination, there is mitral valve regurgitation. Which of the following is the most likely complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aschoff’s bodies

  • Aschoff bodies constitute fibrinoid degeneration.
  • Necrosis is surrounded by T cells, Plasma cells and macrophages called Antischow cells (Pathognomic of RF)
  • These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”).
  • Some of the largely altered histiocytes become multinucleated to form Aschoff Giant cells.

Option A: Erythema multiforme

  • Erythema multiforme is a skin reaction due to type IV hypersensitivity, mostly triggered by infections, medications or other conditions.
  • It causes severe skin eruption that results in small red raised or target lesions all over the body, as given in the image.
  • Steven-Johnson syndrome is a major form of erythema multiforme.
  • Erythema multiforme does not accompany Rheumatic fever.

Option B: Janeway's lesion

  • Janeway's lesions are non-tender, macular and erythematous lesions on the palms and soles of the patient, as given in the image.
  • These are mostly present in the hand's thenar and hypothenar surface and the toes' plantar surface.
  • The duration is usually from days to weeks.
  • It is associated with acute infective endocarditis.

Option D: Osler nodes

  • Osler nodes are tender, violaceous nodules typically located in the pulp of fingers and toes seen in the patient, as given in the image.
  • These are usually transient and removed within days.
  • It is associated with acute infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presented in OPD with complaints of burning epigastrium, dyspepsia and a metallic taste in his mouth for the last 2-years. He has been prescribed omeprazole and over-the-counter antacids, to which he responded partially. He underwent upper GI endoscopy with biopsy, which confirmed the diagnosis of Barrett’s oesophagus. Which of the following is the histological hallmark for the diagnosis of Barrett's oesophagus?

choices.text: Patient may lead to malignancy after few years

questions.solution:
Option D: Squamous to columnar metaplasia

Barrett's oesophagus

  • A complication of chronic GERD
  • Characterised by intestinal metaplasia within oesophagal squamous mucosa. [i.e. squamous to intestinal columnar metaplasia]
  • Increased risk of oesophagal adenocarcinoma.

 

 

Option A: Goblet cells seen on histology

  • Goblet cells can be seen in Barrett’s oesophagus, but it is not the essential feature for diagnosing Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

 

Option B: Presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges

  • Keratin pearls and intercellular bridges are the hallmarks of squamous cell carcinoma
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

 

Option C: Columnar to squamous metaplasia

  • In Barrett's oesophagus, there is a change in epithelium from squamous to columnar
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: An enzyme catalyzing the reaction A + E → EA → E + P was mixed with 5 mM substrate concentration (compound A). The initial rate of formation of the product was 25% of Vmax. What is the Km value for the enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 15 mM:

  • This problem can be solved using the Michaelis–Menten equation.
  • Michaelis–Menten equation: V= (Vmax x [S]) / ([S] + Km)

Where,

V = velocity of the reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity

S = Substrate concentration

Km= Michaelis constant

Given that, the velocity (v) = 25% of Vmax, and substrate concentration [S] = 5 mM

So, 25% Vmax = (Vmax × 5)/ (Km + 5)

Or, ¼ = 5/(Km + 5)                                   [as 25% = ¼]

Or, Km + 5 = 20

Or, Km = 20-5

 So, Km = 15mM

The Michaelis-Menten kinetic equation is one of the best-known formulas of enzyme kinetics.

It can determine the kinetics of enzyme-controlled reactions, where the biochemical reaction is supposed to include a single substrate.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: Refer to the explanation of D

questions.text: A 26-year-old female was talking with her friends in a park in the morning. Suddenly she was fainted and feeling some confusion and was brought to the emergency room. Her vitals came to be, blood pressure 100/70mmhg. GCS score was 14. Her mother told that recently she has been drinking more amount of water and daily she has been going to toilet for more times and increased appetite. Also, the patient complained that she had a fruity smell in her breathe. Patient is undergoing in deficiency of certain substance that normally:

choices.text: Increases renal threshold for glucose reabsorption

questions.solution:
Patient has the classic symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis. DKA can come as a result of diabetic mellitus which is not yet diagnosed. Initial presentation of DM can be DKA mainly in people without regular health check-up.

Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, these are the 3 main cardinal signs of DM. Deficiency of insulin and excess of glucagon along with adrenergic activation and increased level of cortisol and growth hormone. People who are already with diabetics cannot synthesize sufficient amount of insulin and to inhibit glucagon’s effect. Insulin will inhibit actions of glucagon.

In patients with DM and DKA glucose is easily passed on to the cells and the body can notice a sign of hypoglycemia and a state of starvation despite high serum glucose level. In adipose tissue ketoacid synthesis can be stimulated by glucagon because instead of glucose, ketoacids can be used by the cells for the energy during starvation. Glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, lipolysis and urea production can be increased by glucagon.

Signs of DKA include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, tachycardia, tachypnoea, lethargy.

Option A : Insulin does not affect the process of glomerular filtration in which glucose filtered from blood in glomerular capillaries in bowman’s capsule which is then collected in PCT.

Option D : Increased glucose in blood, increased amino acid concentration, cholecystokinin, acetyl choline, these all factors can increase glucagon secretion.

Educational Objective; glucagon actions are opposed by insulin. List of process which glucagon stimulate is gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, lipolysis, amino acid and potassium uptake by cells, lipolysis and ketone body production while insulin increases glucose uptake.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy, from a first-cousin consanguineous couple with history of change in colour of urine to black on exposure to air was diagnosed with Alkaptonuria. Which of the following accumulates abnormally in urine in such patients?
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria

  • Defect in catabolism of Tyrosine and Phenylalanine.
  • Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase.
  • Urine turns black on exposure to air due to oxidation of homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine.
  • Dark staining of diapers
  • Deposition of black pigments (polymerization of homogentisic acid occurring in body over years) in joints, cartilage and collagenous tissue, known as ochronosis. First pigment gets deposited in sclera, ear and nose cartilage, intervertebral discs, joints (ochronotic arthritis).
  • Later knee, shoulders, hips are also affected (small joints of hands and feet are spared)

DEPOSITION OF BLACK PIGMENTS ADDITIONAL EDGE ON THIS TOPIC

CATABOLISM OF PHENYLALANINE AND TYROSINE

questions.text: One enzyme can catalyze the same reaction on a group of structurally similar compounds. Which of the following best describes this statement?
questions.solution:
SPECIFICITY OF ENZYMES

Absolute Specificity

Some enzymes are absolutely specific. For example, hydrolysis of urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide is catalyzed by urease. Urea is the only substrate forurease. Thiourea, though structurally similar to urea, will not act as the substrate for urease. Similarly glucose oxidase will oxidize only beta-D-glucose and no other isomeric form. Thus, these enzymes show absolute specificity.

Bond Specificity

Most of the proteolytic enzymes are showing group (bond) specificity. For example, trypsin can hydrolyze peptide bonds formed by carboxyl groups of arginine or lysine residues in any protein

Group Specificity

One enzyme can catalyze the same reaction on a group of structurally similar compounds, e.g. hexokinase can catalyze phosphorylation of glucose, galactose and mannose.

Stereospecificity

Human enzymes are specific for L-amino acids and D-sugars. Fumarase will hydrate fumaric acid (transform) to malic acid; but the corresponding cis form, maleic acid will not be acted upon. Lactate dehydrogenase, acting on pyruvate will form only L-lactate, but not the D variety.

questions.text: A middle aged women presents with fissures in mouth, tingling sensation and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this:   (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Vitamin B2 , also known as Warburg Yellow enzyme.

  • Active form of this is FMN, FAD. It is involved in oxidation-reduction reactions.
  • In its deficiency, there is decreased activity of glutathione reductase, as this enzyme is dependent on FAD.

B2 Deficiency: Riboflavinosis--->characterized by:

  • Corneal vascularization (earliest sign of deficiency).
  • Glossitis – inflammation of the tongue (magenta tongue- characteristic)
  • Cheilosis – redness and shiny appearance of lips
  • Angular stomatitis (lesions at the mucocutaneous junction at corners of the mouth), leading to painful fissures
  • Seborrheic dermatitis – rough scaly skin because of desquamation

Option 2- Vitamin B1 – Thiamin Nutritional Status can Be assessed by Erythrocyte Transketolase Activity - Thiamin deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option 3-Vitamin B6 - The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by measuring the activity of erythrocyte transaminases.

-The active form of vitamin B6 is the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

- Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness and mental confusion.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented to the physician's office with complaints of polyuria, polydipsia, and increased hunger for the past week. She has had type I diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years with good blood sugar levels control by regular insulin injections. Her mother says that she has been very busy recently with her exams and college routine, which is why she might have carelessly avoided her insulin shots. Which of the following will occur normally in her body during this state?

choices.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA

questions.solution:
Option C: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA

  • In diabetics, the situation is the same as in fasting, i.e., breakdown or catabolism will be increased, and anabolism or synthesis will be decreased.
  • In the absence of insulin, a patient with type I diabetes mellitus will have increased glucagon and epinephrine release. The decreased ratio of insulin/counter-regulatory hormones promotes a catabolic period characterized by the degradation of triglycerides, glycogen, and proteins.

Option A: Glycogenesis in muscle

  • In the absence of insulin, the body shifts to a catabolic metabolism due to decreased ratio of insulin/counter-regulatory hormones leading to decreased glycogenesis

Option B: Increased protein synthesis

  • In diabetes, there is greater protein breakdown for providing substrates of gluconeogenesis since the body switches to a catabolic metabolism when insulin is absent.

Option D: Decreased cholesterol synthesis

  • There is increased cholesterol synthesis in patients with diabetes mellitus. This is because not all the free fatty acids flooding the liver can be disposed of through oxidation or ketone body formation.
  • Increased acetyl CoA formation during the beta-oxidation of the fatty acids leads to increased synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA, which converts to mevalonate, which will ultimately result in increased production of cholesterol.

questions.text: Sugars with major function of providing energy are also involved in a variety of functions such as cell signalling and recognition, extracellular matrix components etc. Which of the following sugars is not seen in the human body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: L-Fructose

  • L-fructose is not seen in the human body.
  • All sugars in our body are D-sugars.
  • All amino acids in human proteins are L-amino acids.
  • But there are exceptions. (L-sugar found in the human body, i.e., L-fucose)

Incorrect options

Option A: L-Fucose

  • Is a Methyl pentose

 

  • Found in glycoproteins and GAGs, e.g., Blood group antigen and part of keratan sulphate
  • Also used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and dietary supplements.

Option C: D-Glucose

  • Most of the dietary polysaccharides and disaccharides get converted to D-Glucose before absorption.
  • So, it is significant sugar present in our dietary carbohydrates
  • Mainly exist as pyranose form (six-membered ring)
  • It's a dextrorotatory sugar (rotate the plane of polarized light to the right)

Option D: D-fructose

  • Major sugar present in fruits and honey
  • Obtained from sucrose and high fructose corn syrup
  • Primarily exists as a furanose form (five-membered ring)
  • It's a levorotatory sugar (rotate the plane of polarized light to the left)

questions.text: Hyaluronic acid is an important component of the extracellular matrix in body tissues. Which of the following are its characteristics?

choices.text: Longest glycosaminoglycan and has glucuronic acid
Has N-acetyl neuraminic acid and glucuronic acid
Has Iduronic acid and is positively charged

questions.solution:
Option A: Longest glycosaminoglycan and has glucuronic acid

  • Hyaluronic acid is the longest GAG and has glucuronic acid.
  • Made up of N-acetyl glucosamine + D-glucuronic Acid as a repeating unit ranging from 5000 to 25000.
  • Hyaluronic acid is negatively charged owing to carboxyl groups in repeating D-glucuronic acid, and bind large quantities of water, thus making it useful as a lubricant in joints, the eye, and the ECM vitreous.
  • Does not contain any sulfate.
  • Provides tensile strength, elasticity, and a slippery nature due to negative charges in the molecule repelling each other.

Option B: N-acetyl galactosamine (GalNAc)

  • It is an amide derivative of the monosaccharide galactose. It is a secondary amide between galactosamine and acetic acid.
  • It is a component of chondroitin sulfate and dermatan sulfate (a description of these GAGs is given in earlier questions)

Option C: N-acetyl neuraminic Acid (NeuNAc or NANA) and glucuronic acid

  • It is an N-acetyl derivative of neuraminic acid (a nine-carbon sugar derived from mannosamine)
  • It is a major component of bacterial cell wall peptidoglycans.
  • It is also present in the keratan sulfate in a minor amount.
  • Although HA contains glucuronic acid, it is connected to glucosamine and not N-acetyl neuraminic acid, making this option the wrong choice.

Option D: Contains Iduronic Acid and is positively charged.

  • It is an acid derivative of aldohexose sugar idose, which is not present freely in nature.
  • It is a component of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate.
  • Hyaluronic acid is highly negatively charged.

questions.text: TCA reactions are happening in mitochondrial matrix for effective utilization of reduced coenzymes generated in TCA through ETC. All of the following TCA cycle dehydrogenase are located in the mitochondrial matrix, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase

  • Also known as succinate-coenzyme Q reductase or respiratory complex II is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • It is the only enzyme simultaneously taking part in TCA and electron transport chain.
  • The FAD cofactor is covalently attached to this enzyme.
  • The electrons transferred from the succinate are directly fed into the electron transport chain through the reduced coenzyme FADH2.

Option A, B and D: Malate dehydrogenase, Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and isocitrate dehydrogenase

  • All of these dehydrogenases are present in the mitochondrial matrix.
  • For reaction catalyzed by these enzymes, see TCA cycle diagram below.

  • Malate dehydrogenase is a simple dehydrogenase which only performs oxidation of substrate malate whereas other two dehydrogenases are complex dehydrogenases doing both oxidation and decarboxylation of the substrate to give rise to CO2 and NADH2

questions.text: In which of these locations is the sodium-iodide symporter not present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ovaries:

Sodium-iodide symporter:

  • The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is not present in the ovaries. NIS is responsible for iodide uptake in various organs like the thyroid glands, mammary glands, placenta, etc., but it is not found in the ovaries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • The thyroid glands, mammary glands, and placenta all contain NIS and utilize it for iodide uptake, serving various physiological functions.

questions.text: 7-years-old Mike was taken to the pediatrician by his parents. They complained that, instead of going out and playing with other children their son is always remaining back in their home. And recently they also noticed that their son was feeling some difficulty in walking too. After a primary set of analgesic management, the problem was not getting solved. So that during the review of the patient, the physical examination revealed that Mike had a weakness in the lower extremity muscles. The doctor ordered for a biopsy from the calf muscle and the report came to be as shown in the figure. Which of the marked region contains thick filaments?
questions.solution:
Myosin- thick filaments are present only in the H band region of the sarcomere. It is a portion of A band and sharing with M line. Whole thick myosin filament is corresponded by A band which includes the portions which have been overlapped by thin actin filaments. During the time of contraction, by decreasing the size of H band, actin filaments will be sliding over the myosin filaments towards the M line. Contracted sarcomere has been shown in the given micrograph. On the contracted sarcomere H band will be narrower, with lucent over either side of the M line.

Option A : This is the area were cross connections are there which can hold the actin thin filaments in a proper manner.

Option B : Only actin thin filaments are contained in this part of I band. I band and H band both will get decreased during contraction.

Option C : This is the part that corresponds to the myosin thick filaments. This is part of A band in the sarcomere. Both myosin filaments will be overlapped with thin filaments of actin in this region. Also, non-overlapped myosin filaments are also seen here. This band will not be getting shortened during contraction.

Educational objective; Myosin thick filaments are present only in the H band region of the sarcomere. Region were myosin thick filaments are not having any overlapping thin filaments is the part of A band on either side of M line.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presented with complaints of coughing & dysphagia for 1 week duration. You are auscultating the patient to rule out esophageal dysmotility. TRUE about boundary of triangle of auscultation is:
questions.solution:
Triangle of auscultation helps in hearing breath sounds clearly and splash sound of food entering stomach.

The triangle is formed by:

  • Trapezius - medial border
  • Lattismus Dorsii - lower border and
  • Scapula- lateral border

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus came for regular follow-up & to get his maintenance medications. The activity of which of the following enzyme is increased in Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic situation is same like fasting or starvation i.e. catabolic situation in the body.
  • So, in Diabetes Mellitus, the activity of Catabolic enzymes is increased.
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) is an enzyme of β-Oxidation which is a Catabolic pathway. Therefore, it is increased in Diabetes.
  • Option b & c - Phosphoenol Pyruvate Carboxykinase (PEPCK) and Glucose -6-Phosphatase are enzymes of Gluconeogenesis which is a Catabolic pathway and hence increased in Diabetes.
  • So, answer is all.

questions.text: Activation of PKG by c GMP In vascular smooth muscle leads to:

choices.text: Activating  IP3-mediated Ca2+ release from intracellular stores
Phosphorylation of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to inhibit Ca2+ influx
Dephosphorylation of phospholamban, a modulator of the sarcoplasmic Calcium pump, leading to a more rapid reuptake of Ca2+ into intracellular stores
Dephosphorylation  and closing  the Ca2+-activated K+ channel

questions.solution:
Activation of PKG by c GMP In vascular smooth muscle leads to vasodilation by-

• Inhibiting IP3-mediated Ca2+ release from intracellular stores

• Phosphorylating voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to inhibit Ca2+ influx

• Phosphorylating phospholamban, a modulator of the sarcoplasmic Ca2+ pump, leading to a more rapid reuptake of Ca2+ into intracellular stores

• Phosphorylating and opening the Ca2+-activated K+ channel, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell membrane, which closes L-type Ca2+ channels and reduces the flux of Ca2+ into the cell

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of fall and on X ray is detected with a spinal vertebral fracture. On neuro-examination the doctor finds that the pain and temperature sensations on the opposite side of the body, distal to the injury are absent. Which spinal pathway has been distrupted?
questions.solution:
Ascending and Descending (Motor) Tracts
Number Path Function Side of Body
1 Anterior corticospinal tract Skilled movement Opposite
2 Vestibulospinal tract Facilitates extensor muscle tone Same
3 Lateral corticospinal (Pyramidal tract) Skilled movement Same
4 Dorsolateral fasciculus Pain and temperature Bidirectional
5 Fasciculus proprius Short spinal connections Bidirectional
6 Fasciculus gracilis Position/ fine touch Same
7 Fasciculus cuneatus Position/ fine touch Same
8 Lateran spinothalamic tract Pain and temperature Opposite
9 Anterior spinothalamic tract Light touch Opposite

Learning objective : Knowledge of the pathways of the spinal cord will make one diagnose the location of pathology on a simple neurological assessment. Combined with radiology it helps a doctor to properly diagnose and manage a patient.

questions.text: Calculate the plasma osmolality of a child with plasma Na+ 125 mEq/L, glucose 108 mg/dL, and BUN (blood urea Nitrogen) 140mg/dL?
questions.solution:
The plasma osmolality can be calculated based on the following formula:

Osmolality = 2x [Na+] + [glucose]/18+ [BUN]/2.8

Putting these values in formula:

= 2× 125 + 108/18 + 140/2.8

= 250 + 6 + 50

= 306 m Osm/kg.

questions.text:
Microcytic hypochromic anemia is seen in -

Anemia of chronic disease
Thalassemia
Iron deficiency
Fanconi’s anemia
questions.solution:
Fanconi's Anemia does not cause microcytic hypochromic anemia.

The causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia are:

  • S = Sideroblastic Anemia
  • I = Iron deficiency Anemia
  • T = Thalassemia
  • A = Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant was brought in with a history of abdominal distension. Further history revealed absence of stool passage. Clinical evaluation revealed a diagnosis of Hirschprung’s disease. In Hirschsprung’s disease, aganglionic segment is:
questions.solution:
• Occurs in 1 out of every 5000 live birthsQ
  • MC affected site: Rectosigmoid (75%)Q >splenic flexure or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension into the small bowelQ (8%)
  • Increased Risk : Positive family historyQ and Down syndromeQ

Pathogenesis

  • Characterized pathologically by absent ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) and submucosal (Meissner’s) plexus with hypertrophy of nerve trunksQ in the plexus
  • Associated with muscular spasm of the distal colon and internal anal sphincter resulting in a functional obstructionQ
  • Abnormal bowel is the contracted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal, dilated portionQ.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 103 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 103 /µl. Which of the following is the reason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

choices.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow
Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Release pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation:

  • The increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report is likely due to the release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation in response to the traumatic physical event. During acute severe inflammation or stress responses such as trauma, the number of white blood cells stored in the bone marrow can be rapidly released into circulation, leading to leukocytosis.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow: Increased production of white blood cells by the bone marrow is not likely within the short span of time between the accident and the blood test. Leukocytosis due to increased production typically occurs in prolonged inflammatory conditions or in leukemias.

Option C - Decreased destruction of WBCs: Decreased destruction of white blood cells is unlikely to be the cause of increased white blood cell count in this scenario, as there is no indication of a viral infection or other condition that would disrupt normal bone marrow function.

Option D - Increased production of selectins: Increased production of selectins is not directly related to the release of stored white blood cells from the bone marrow. Selectins play a role in inflammation and immune responses but do not regulate the release of stored white blood cells into circulation in response to acute traumatic events.

questions.text: Calculate AUC for a drug M, which was given as a single bolus dose of 50mg given IV . drug M has Vd 150 litres and elimination rate constant of 0.2 h-1
questions.solution:
As per the question

·         elimination rate constant = 0.2 h-1

·         Vd = 150 litres

·         single bolus dose = 50mg

·         Bioavailability(F) = 1 as the drug is given IV

clearance = K X Vd

=  0.2 x 150 = 30  

AUC = F X Dose administered/ clearance           

  = 1 x 50 / 30      

       = 1.66 mg.h/L

questions.text: A 30-years-old patient presented to medicine department last year with paint in small joints of hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and started on methotrexate. Patient did not respond to methotrexate and was started on a different drug. Patient came to medicine OPD today with gingival hyperplasia. Which of the following drug patient was most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine (calcineurin inhibitor) is an immunosuppressant drug. It is used as second line drug in autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. It is often used along with corticosteroids and methotrexate to suppress acute exacerbations. It is associated with side effects such as tremor, hallucinations, drowsiness, coma, nephrotoxicity, hypertension, hirsutism, hyperlipidemia and gum hyperplasia (as in this patient).

A) Prednisolone (corticosteroid) has immunosuppressant and anti-inflammatory action. They can be introduced at any stage of RA. The side effects include- ↑ blood glucose, hypertension, cushingoid habitus, ↑ weight, ↑ risk of infection, osteoporosis, glaucoma, cataracts, depression, anxiety, psychosis. Long-term treatment ⇒ adrenal suppression; withdraw slowly on alternate days

C) Azathioprine (cytotoxic agent) is less commonly used in rheumatoid arthritis. It has steroid sparing effect. It is associated with side effects such as bone marrow suppression, increased susceptibility to infections, hepatotoxicity, alopecia and GI toxicity

D) Mycophenolate mofetil (cytotoxic drug). It is used as add on drug to cyclosporine and steroids in renal transplantation. It can cause diarrhea, vomiting) and hematologic (leukopenia, pure red cell aplasia) problems

questions.text: A 45-years-old patient came to the hospital with shortness of breath and swollen legs. He was diagnosed with congestive heart failure and started on furosemide. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality caused by furosemide can precipitate cardiac arrhythmia if patient is started on digoxin?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypercalcemia increase the arrhythmogenic effect of digoxin

Pharmacotherapy of heart failure (as in this patient) include diuretics, digoxin, vasodilators, ACEIs and beta blockers.

Loop diuretics (such as furosemide) inhibit the Na+/K+/2Cl- co-transporter in the thick ascending limb of renal tubule, causing loss of Na+, K+ and Cl- ions in the urine. This also disrupts electrochemical gradient that facilitates paracellular reabsorption of Ca+ and Mg+, thus causing excretion of these ions. Increased Na+ delivery to the distal tubule, particularly when combined with activation of the renin–angiotensin system, leads to increased urinary K+ and H+ excretion, causing a hypochloremic alkalosis. If dietary K+ intake is not sufficient, hypokalemia may develop, and this may induce cardiac arrhythmias, particularly in patients taking cardiac glycosides. Increased Mg2+ and Ca2+ excretion may result in hypomagnesemia (a risk factor for cardiac arrhythmias) and hypocalcemia (rarely leading to tetany).

Digoxin (cardiac glycoside) inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase of myocardial fibres, alters the driving force for sodium-calcium exchange and results in increased intracellular calcium which ultimately increases myocardial contractility. The major signs of digoxin toxicity are arrhythmias.

  1. Hyponatremia and hypocalcemia are seen with loop diuretics; however, it will not increase arrhythmogenic effect of digoxin
  2. Hypernatremia and hyperkalemia are not seen with loop diuretics
  3. Hyponatremia is seen with loop diuretics, but it will not increase the risk of arrhythmia in this patient. Hypermagnesemia is not seen with loop diuretics

Learning objective:

  • Overall, loop diuretics cause electrolyte abnormalities in the form of hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.
  • Digoxin should be avoided in patients on loop diuretics as electrolyte abnormalities caused by loop diuretics (especially hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia) can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmia

questions.text: A 60-years-old man came to the hospital complaining of severe pain, swelling and redness at the metatarsophalangeal joint of his left big toe. He has BMI of 34 with history of hypertension. Which of the following drug could be the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is showing signs and symptoms of acute gout. As patient is hypertensive, he might be taking thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone) and long-term use of thiazides can cause increase in blood urate levels.

Thiazide diuretics inhibit NaCl transport in the DCT. Most serious adverse effects of thiazides include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Because of their tendency to cause hyperuricemia, they can precipitate an acute attack of gout as seen in this patient. Simple review of medication will relieve symptoms of this patient.

  1. Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker
  2. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor
  3. Telmisartan is an ARB (Except chlorthalidone, rest of the drugs have no effect on serum uric acid levels)

Learning objective: Thiazides cause hyperuricemia, therefore to be used with caution in patients who are at increased risk for gout.

questions.text: A 65-years-old man presented to the clinic with a complaint of urinary incontinence. He was started on a new drug Mirabegron which is a beta 3 receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. All of the following is true regarding Mirabegron EXCEPT:

choices.text: It increases the incidence of urinary tract infections

questions.solution:
Mirabegron a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence. Side effects include increased blood pressure, increased incidence of urinary tract infection, and headache. Mirabegron is also a moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor, so care must be taken when prescribing with other drugs metabolized by CYP2D6, such as digoxin, metoprolol, and desipramine.

A) Mirabegron can cause rise in blood pressure

B) It is associated with increase in incidence of urinary tract infection

C) It is associated with adverse effect of headache

Learning objective : Mirabegron (β3 adrenergic receptor agonist) is a CYP2D6 inhibitor, so it can cause drug interactions with other drugs metabolized by CYP2D6.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented to the general OPD with complaints of colicky pain in the abdomen following a meal for 1 hour. She was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. Open cholecystectomy was performed. She was kept post-operatively in the surgical ward for a few days and given anticoagulants. Which of the following statement is true regarding warfarin?

choices.text: They interfere with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
These can produce anticoagulant effects both in vivo and in vitro.
These can produce bleeding like hematuria and cerebral haemorrhage
Their action starts immediately, so they are helpful for the initiation of therapy in deep vein thrombosis

questions.solution:
Option C: These can produce bleeding like hematuria and cerebral haemorrhage.

  • In this case, the 45-year-old lady presented with typical cholecystitis symptoms: colicky abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, worsened after meal intake. She underwent open cholecystectomy for the treatment of acute cholecystitis. Post-op care generally involves using anticoagulants, physiotherapy and compression stockings to avoid deep venous thrombosis due to immobility.
  • Drugs in the warfarin group, or oral anticoagulants, include warfarin, dicumarol, phenindione etc.
  • These drugs inhibit the activation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. These factors include clotting factors II, VII, IX and X.
  • The onset of oral anticoagulants develops gradually over 1-3 days, thus used for the maintenance of anticoagulation.
  • Bleeding is the most common adverse effect of all anticoagulants. It can present as hematuria and severe cases, even cerebral haemorrhage.
  • Phenindione causes orange-coloured urine as well as hepatotoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

Option A: They interfere with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

  • Synthesis of these factors remains unaffected.
  • The mechanism of action of these drugs merely involves the inhibition of activation of vitamin K-dependent factors.

Option B: These can produce anticoagulant effects in vivo and in vitro.

  • These drugs do not affect already formed factors, so these are not effective in vitro.

Option D: Their action starts immediately, so they are helpful for the initiation of therapy in deep vein thrombosis.
