  • Since they affect only the activation of clotting factors rather than their synthesis, the therapeutic effect is gradual.
  • The first factor to disappear is factor VII (t1/2= 6 hours), and the last to disappear is factor II (t1/2= 60 hours).
  • They are therefore used for maintenance rather than induction.

questions.text: A patient Who has a history of sulfa allergy presents with features consistent with Acute congestive glaucoma . Which of the following drug should be avoided in this patient ?
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide:It has the potential to cause SJS in patients of sulfa allergy

MOA :Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase isozymes present in ciliary processes of the eye with the consequent reduction of bicarbonate and aqueous humor secretion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with end-stage cystic fibrosis undergoes lung transplantation. Three years later, he has a 6-month progressive decline in his renal function. Which of the following medications is the most likely etiology of this?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease is a common finding in patients after lung transplantation and is associated with poorer outcomes. While rarely patients may have hemolytic-uremic syndrome underlying the kidney disease, it is usually acute, and the most common etiology of gradually progressive decline in renal function is calcineurin inhibitor neuropathy. Cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors commonly used in immunosuppressive regimens after lung transplantation. The exact mechanism of this toxicity is unclear but may include direct toxicity of inhibition of the calcineurin-NFAT system within the kidney, alteration in glomerular blood flow, and host/environment interactions within the kidney with calcineurin inhibitors.

Prednisone, albuterol, and mycophenolate mofetil are not known to be nephrotoxic.

INCORRECT OPTION

OPTION A : Prednisiolone administered after lung transplasnsation prevents damage to transplanted lungs by the immune system. Side effects of long-term prednisolone therapy include atrophy of the adrenal gland and osteonecrosis of Hip joint.

OPTION C : Albuterol (Salbutamol) short-acting β? adrenergic receptor agonist is useful in exacerbation of asthma by dilating the airway by acting on smooth muscles.

OPTION D : Mycophenolate mofetil action by selective inhibition of B cell and T-cell proliferation by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the de novo pathway of purine synthesis. Declining renal function is not seen with the use of mycophenolate.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE : Chronic kidney disease is a common finding in patients after lung transplantation and is associated with poorer outcomes. The most common etiology of gradually progressive decline in renal function is calcineurin inhibitor neuropathy. Cyclosporine and tacrolimus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, vomiting and anorexia for four days. Colonoscopy shows inflammation with knife-like fissures in the terminal ileum with a gross appearance of cobblestone mucosa. The patient is initially treated with methylprednisolone IV daily, but the patient's condition has not improved despite adequate steroid therapy. Which of the following drug will be used for the treatment of this steroid-resistant disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Infliximab

  • The colonoscopic findings of inflammation in the terminal ileum with knife-like fissures and the cobblestone appearance of the mucosa suggest the diagnosis of Crohn's disease.
  • Infliximab can be used in steroid-resistant cases of Chron’s disease.
  • It is a recombinant humanized monoclonal anti-tumor necrosis factor-alpha (anti-TNF-α) antibody that helps prevent synovial and intestinal inflammation.
  • It is indicated in the following conditions:
    • For moderately-to-severely active Crohn's disease in patients who have had an inadequate response to conventional therapy like steroid therapy.
    • It can also be used as primary therapy for induction and maintenance
    • Plaque psoriasis
    • Ulcerative colitis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
    • Psoriatic arthritis

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Leflunomide

  • Leflunomide, a non-biological DMARD, inhibits pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis, and it is also antiproliferative for T-cells.
  • It is primarily used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B: Mesalamine

  • As the patient is diagnosed with severe Crohn's disease, infliximab can be used for induction. Mesalamine is mainly used for mild Crohn's disease.
  • Although the specific mechanism of action of mesalamine is unknown, it probably inhibits the synthesis and release of prostaglandins and leukotrienes in the colon.
  • It is primarily used in ulcerative colitis in the remission induction of active, mild to moderate disease and in remission maintenance.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Only infliximab will be used in this scenario as the patient is diagnosed with severe Crohn's disease.
  • Methotrexate is an alternative for maintenance therapy in Crohn’s disease for patients who do not tolerate thiopurines
  • Methotrexate impedes dihydrofolic acid reductase and blocks the production of purine and thymidylic acid.
  • Therefore, it interferes with DNA synthesis, repair, and cellular replication.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and his pulse is 85 beats/minute. His has a laceration on the right arm. A local anesthetic composed of lidocaine and adrenaline was administered to the patient before the physician cleaned and debrided the wound. Why did the anesthetist use adrenaline in addition to lidocaine for anesthesia?

choices.text: Duration of action can be prolonged

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: All of the above 

  • Adrenaline is a vasoconstrictor and can be added to lidocaine to decrease the rate of systemic absorption from the injection site, this can help in:
    • Prolonging the duration of action of lidocaine 
    • Decreasing the risk of systemic side effects
    • Decreasing bleeding during procedures 
    • Higher doses of lidocaine can be given at the site or at multiple sites
  • Lidocaine with adrenaline SHOULD NOT be used for:
    • Areas with end arteries, e.g. fingers, toes, penis, pinna (absolute contraindication) as it can lead to ischemia of that area.
  • Adrenaline should be avoided in patients who have received halothane and have increased sensitivity of the myocardium. 
    • Myocardial ischemic patients
    • Hyperthyroid patient
    • Severe hypertensives 
    • Intravenous regional anaesthesia

 

Option A: Decrease the systemic toxicity 

  • Adrenaline decreases the absorption of lidocaine and decreases the risk of systemic toxicity. 

 

Option B: High Doses can be given 

  • Because of the vasoconstriction properties of adrenaline, higher doses of lidocaine can be given with it, resulting in a slower release of medication. 

 

Option C: Duration of action can be prolonged 

  • Adrenaline increases the duration of action of lidocaine by gradually releasing the medication from the injection site.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for nonsevere Clostridium difficile colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vancomycin:

  • For patients with nonsevere C. difficile colitis, oral fidaxomicin(200 mg orally two times daily) and vancomycin (125 mg orally, four times daily) are effective for initial treatment.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are nor used in the treatment of patients with C. difficile colitis

questions.text: Which of the following opportunistic infections in AIDS is treated by cotrimoxazole?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pneumocystis jiroveci

  • Pneumocystis jiroveci causes pneumonia in AIDS as the CD4 count falls below 100/mm3.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis pneumonia.
  • It is also used as a prophylaxis for Pneumocystis Jirovecii pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals for CD4 counts less than 200.

Option A: Disseminated Herpes simplex

  • Herpes simplex can cause disseminated infection in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Acyclovir is the drug of choice for the herpes simplex virus.
  • Cotrimoxazole is not an antiviral drug.

Option B: Cryptococcal meningitis

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungus that can cause meningitis in AIDS.
  • Drugs used for cryptococcal meningitis include:
    • Acute phase: amphotericin B
    • Maintenance phase: Fluconazole
  • Cotrimoxazole is not an antifungal drug.

Option D: Tuberculosis

  • TB can cause infection in immunocompromised patients.
  • Anti-TB drugs should be used in these patients following the 6-month regimen.
  • Cotrimoxazole is not an anti-TB drug.

questions.text: A 28-years-old woman is brought to the psychiatry out-patient department accompanied by her husband. The patient appears quiet during the interview and looks down most of the time. The husband explains how less interested she would appear in most of the activities they would enjoy earlier. He also mentioned of her recent episodes of irritability towards her children on trivial provocations. She is found to have increased her alcohol intake recently from occasional to once a week. She would be lethargic most of the times and would wake up early than her usual days. The husband recalls her wife brought to a psychiatrist 7 years back for decreased need for sleep and over-religiosity. She would then talk relentlessly, unlike now, when she would appear agitated most of the times. What would be the most appropriate line of management in this case?

choices.text: Enrolling her in a deaddiction programme

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

D) Lithium: It is a mood stabilizer given for the treatment of acute and maintenance phase of bipolar affective disorder. The patient in given scenario is having a major depressive episode, with a history of manic/hypomanic episode in the past. In case for the current episode, she is started on antidepressant alone, she would switch into a manic episode, thus leading to a poor prognosis in the long term. Lithium and Lamotrigine are preferred drugs of choice in bipolar depression.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Reassurance and marital therapy: The patient is having clinical depressive episode impairing her socio-occupational functioning. Moreover, she has a past history of bipolar mania, thus requires pharmacological intervention and mere reassurance will lead to a delay in management. Marital conflict is not mentioned in the clinical case scenario, hence, is not the preferred treatment option.

(B) Enrolling her in a deaddiction program: Increase in substance use is common in both manic and atypical depressive episodes. The treatment of the affective episodes will lead to the control of the use of substances.

(C) Sertraline: It is an antidepressant (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor). It is preferred for major depressive episodes/ unipolar depression. If given in a patient with bipolar affective disorder, it is preferred with a concurrent administration of mood-stabilizers, to prevent and affective switch.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Bipolar affective disorder is characterised by one or more episodes of mania or hypomania, lasting for a duration of 1 week or more. It is treated with the use of mood stabilizer along with antipsychotic during the acute phase, and maintenance treatment with mood stabilizer only.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman with a history of multiple spontaneous abortions is brought to the Obstetric ER for an urgent ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis. On questioning about the reason, she mentions about her 14 weeks of gestation. The accompanying husband reassures her about the last few ultrasonography’s, not revealing any viable fetuses, but the woman insists on getting another examination done. The intern posted in the ER examines her and reassures her about her non-pregnant state. She, in disbelief, breaks the glass of the ER entrance and leaves the premises angrily. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

(C) Pseudocyesis: The woman in the question has a false belief of being pregnant, due to the objective signs of amenorrhea, obesity, subjective sensation of fetal movement, breast enlargement, even labor pains. This phenomenon is termed as pseudocyesis. It is a type of delusional disorder, and it is best managed with anti-psychotics if reassurance does not work.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Ekbom syndrome: It is a delusional disorder in which the affected individual believes of being infested by a parasite,

(B) Couvade syndrome: It is a disorder in which the partners of a pregnant female develop the same experience that their pregnant spouses have. It is also called as sympathy pregnancy. It has not been clinically classified yet.

(D) Cotard’s syndrome: It is a common delusion found in persons with major depressive episode. The affected individual believes that the parts of their body, or whole body is missing, or that they are soiling, dead or does not exist. It can also present as a monosymptomatic delusion where the primary treatment would be an antipsychotic agent.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Delusional disorders present in various themes, including persecution, litigious, grandiose, jealousy, and love. The treatment of choice for them includes use of an antipsychotic drug i.e. a Dopamine blocking agent.

questions.text: A 14-year-old youngster struggles to express himself in writing and makes numerous spelling errors. He receives a bad grade on his exam. On the other hand, his intellectual abilities and social adaptability are age appropriate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Specific learning disability

  • Academic difficulty in a particular skill (written expression) suggests a specific learning disability.
  • Significant impairment in one or more academic skills, compared to intellectual functioning (normal IQ), with issues occurring only in one domain.
  1. A specific reading disorder is a condition that affects a person's ability to read (dyslexia).
  2. Disorders of written expression (particular spelling disorder) - makes a lot of mistakes with their spelling.
  3. Specific math skills problems mixed scholastic skill disorders

Option A: Mental retardation

  • A mentally retarded child will have issues with social adaptability.
  • His symptoms are not confined to learning skills.
  • Specific learning disabilities are the more appropriate choice.

Option C: Lack of interest in studies

  • Lack of interest in studies would result in symptoms limited to the examination or schooling.
  • This child's normal social adaptability and low grades with numerous spelling mistakes at this age are concerning for the specific language disorder.

Option D: Examination anxiety

  • Examination anxiety would result in symptoms limited to the examination.
  • This child's normal social adaptability and low grades with numerous spelling mistakes at this age are concerning for the specific language disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with complaints of decreased sexual drive and an inability to achieve an erection for the past four months. His past medical history is unremarkable except for major depressive disorder, for which he has been taking an antidepressant for the past five months. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient's complaints?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fluoxetine

  • SSRIs are the first-line antidepressant medications used for major depressive disorder.
  • There are three most common side effects associated with SSRIs.
  • These include gastrointestinal disturbance, hyponatremia, and sexual dysfunction.
  • All SSRIs cause sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, ejaculatory dysfunction, or anorgasmia.
  • This effect is utilized for therapeutic purposes in patients suffering from premature ejaculation.
  • The sexual dysfunction associated with SSRIs is reversible upon stopping the drug.
  • Sildenafil can also be used to alleviate SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.
  • SSRIs most notorious for sexual dysfunction include paroxetine, fluvoxamine, and fluoxetine.
  • The patient should be counseled regarding the possible side effects when prescribing the drug.
  • Some studies suggest that sexual dysfunction associated with SSRIs may be dose-related, but it has not yet been established.
  • The timing of the onset of symptoms in this stem suggests that the symptoms are secondary to the antidepressant medication.
  • If a person cannot tolerate the side effects of SSRIs, the doctor would need to switch to a different class of antidepressant medications.

Option B: Mirtazapine

  • Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that works by blocking alpha-2 adrenergic receptors.
  • Mirtazapine is especially indicated when the somatic symptoms of depression, e.g., decreased sleep and appetite, predominate.
  • Mirtazapine does not cause sexual dysfunction and is a safe alternative to SSRIs for people suffering from SSRI-induced sexual health problems.

Option C: Bupropion

  • Bupropion is an antidepressant that blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine in the synaptic cleft.
  • It does not affect the serotonin system; thus, it is associated with a low risk of sexual dysfunction.
  • Its efficacy is comparable to SSRIs, and it is increasingly becoming popular as a monotherapy for major depressive disorder.
  • It is famous for its role in smoking cessation.

Option D: None of the above

  • As fluoxetine is the culprit for sexual dysfunction in the above stem, this option is ruled out.

questions.text: A 38 years old male deceased was brought to the Department of Forensic Medicine for post-mortem examination. The deceased died two days back in Dubai after falling in sea, while he was working over cruise. Cause of death given by Dubai authorities was – Death due to drowning after preliminary enquiry and without post-mortem examination. Then dead body was embalmed and handed over to his relatives for funeral procedures in India. All of the following are constituents of embalming solution except:
questions.solution:
• Ethanol is a preservative and can be used for embalming but is not the usual content of embalming fluid/solution. In its place methanol is used, which is cheaper and more toxic to bacteria than ethanol. Methanol also holds the formaldehyde in solution.
  • Embalming is the process of treatment of the dead body with antiseptics and preservatives to prevent putrefaction.
  • Typically, embalming fluid contains a mixture of formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, methanol, and other solvents. The formaldehyde content generally ranges from 5 to 37 percent and the methanol content may range from 9 to 56 percent.
  • Preservative is the substance added to destroy or inhibit the growth of microorganisms. It alters enzymes and lysins of the body and arrest decomposition — fixing the specimen in such a way that it retains its original structure with minimal alteration. Formalin is the most commonly used fixative/ preservative and less commonly used are – Ethanol/ Phenol.
  • Phenol is a powerful Fungicide.
  • Glycerine is used in the embalming fluid as a hygroscopic/humectant/wetting agent and decreases the loss of water of the preserved structures (maintains hydration). But it is not the actual preservative by definition.
  • Wetting agents lower the surface tension of water and facilitate penetration and distribution of embalming fluids through the vascular beds into the tissues.

questions.text: A dead body is recovered with multiple gun shot wounds. On examination, Abrasion collar is seen in the entry wound. Which of the following cannot be determined?
questions.solution:
Abrasion collar/ring :

  • As the bullet strikes the skin, it first indents and then stretches the skin surface so that perforation takes place through a tense area which produces a rim of flattened reddish-brown zone of abraded epidermis, surrounding the entrance wound.
  • The abrasion ring can vary in width, depending on the caliber of the weapon, the angle and site at which the bullet entered.
  • A bullet striking perpendicularly will produce a concentric ring, and if the bullet penetrates at an oblique angle, the zone will be eccentric with the wider zone on the side from which the bullet came

questions.text: According to which section, if a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding
questions.solution:
S 132 IEA - If a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding

S 151 IEA – Court can forbid indecent questions

S 152 IEA– Court can disallow the questions which are insulting/offensive

S 148 IEA– Court to decide when question shall be asked and when witness compelled to answer: Lawyer may attack the character of the witness. Such questions are proper it they are of such a nature that the truth of the imputation conveyed by them would seriously affect the opinion of the Courts as to the credibility of the witness on the matter to which testifies.

questions.text: What is the age of abrasion?
questions.solution:
Scab has amost completely peeled off which indicates age >7 days

Healing of Abrasion

  1. Fresh: Reddish in colour
  2. By 12- 24 hrs: Reddish Scab is formed (the scab formation occurs due to drying of superficial blood and lymph)
  3. By 2-3 days: Reddish brown scab
  4. By 4-7 days:Dark brown scab is formed,Epithelium grows under the scab and eventuallyScab starts falling off from margins
  5. After 7 days: Scab falls off leaving a depigmented area; later becomes pigmented.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been arrested by the police after 3 women filed charges against him for harassing them by indulging in Frotteurism at the park. The police have made the arrest after questioning multiple witnesses from the park that evening. Which act is the man being charged for?

choices.text: Sexual pleasure is obtained by witnessing the act of urination
Sexual gratification by touching or rubbing one’s genitals against another non-consenting individual
Sexual gratification by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by acts of physical cruelty

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sexual gratification by touching or rubbing one’s genitals against another non-consenting individual

  •  It is the act of obtaining sexual arousal and gratification by rubbing of one’s genitals against a non-consenting person in public places : Frotteurism 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sexual pleasure is obtained by witnessing the act of urination:

  • This describes urolagnia. Urolagnia involves sexual arousal or gratification from urine or urination-related activities, such as watching someone urinate or being urinated on.

Option C - Sexual gratification by wearing clothes of the opposite sex:

  • This refers to transvestism or cross-dressing. Transvestism involves deriving sexual gratification from wearing clothing typically associated with the opposite sex.

Option D - Sexual gratification by acts of physical cruelty:

  • This describes sadism. Sadism involves deriving sexual pleasure from inflicting pain, humiliation, or suffering on others. ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 26-year-old man sustained fracture of overlying skull bone after involved in a motor vehicular accident. This finding is usually present with
questions.solution:
Epidural/ Extradural haemorrhage:

  • Bleeding occurring between the inner table of the skull and meninges
  • Least commonintracranial haemorrhage (10%)

Causes : Mostly traumaticin origin, andunilateral.

Salient Features :

  • It occurs usually on the side of the impact (coup injury)
  • Never a counter coup injury
  • Forms a circumscribed ovoid or disk-shaped blood clot

Age group :

  • Common in adults between 20–40 years.
  • Rare in the elderly and children due to greater adherence of dura to the skull.

Fracture (fissure type)is present in most of the cases

questions.text: An 80-year-old man from Nursing Home is brought to the hospital complaining of confusion, fever, and decreased oral intake. The medical conditions include recurrent urinary tract infections, Diabetes mellitus type 2, and hypertension. Two days ago, he underwent a cystoscopy with the removal of a bladder polyp. When the patient is admitted, he requires endotracheal intubation. The ventilator settings are as follows: tidal volume 370 ml, respiratory rate 22 per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure 5 mmHg, FiO2 70%. The arterial blood gas analysis is as follows: pH = 7.4, PaCO2 = 30 mmHg, PO2 = 55 mmHg, Bicarbonate = 21 mEq/L. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increase positive end-expiratory pressure:

  • This patient has respiratory distress after fever requiring intubation due to some infection or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Positive end-expiratory pressure improves oxygenation by recruiting flooded alveoli and popping them open throughout the respiratory cycle. Elevated PEEP is always required in severe respiratory distress like ARDS. Increasing PEEP must be carefully done because it can cause risk of their BAROTRAUMA.
  • So, increasing PEEP has several beneficial effects:
    • Additional alveoli are recruited, making more of the lung available for gas exchange which reduces shunting also. 
    • When more alveolar units are recruited, lung compliance is improved
    • Mean Airway pressure is increased, which provides a larger pressure gradient for oxygen transfer, also known as diffusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase fiO2:

  • Oxygenation can also be improved by increasing high FiO2; patients are often provided with high FiO2 after intubation.
  • FiO2 is usually weaned to less than 60% as quickly as possible to avoid potential oxygen toxicity.

Option C - Increases the respiratory rate:

  • This patient's ventilation is good because there is only mild hypocapnia.
  • The increasing respiratory rate would worsen respiratory alkalosis without improving oxygenation.

Option D - Increase tidal volume:

  • Increasing tidal volume may cause alveolar overdistension, increasing the risk of barotrauma.
  • The ideal tidal volume formula is 6 ml per kg, so this patient tidal volume is consistent with lung protective ventilation commonly used in severe respiratory distress.

questions.text: The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value is the concentration of an inhalation anaesthetic agent in the lung alveoli required to prevent movement in response to a surgical stimulus in 50% of patients. The MAC value gives a rough idea about the potency of the anaesthetics. Which of the following anaesthetic agent has the highest MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration)
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nitrous oxide:

  • Nitrous oxide has the maximum MAC value of 104%
  • The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anaesthetic is defined as that concentration at 1 atmosphere that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a supramaximal painful stimulus (surgical skin incision) in 50% of patients.
  • Immobility produced by inhaled anaesthetics as measured by MAC is mediated principally by the effects of these drugs on the spinal cord, and only a minor component of immobility results from cerebral effects.
  • Nitrous oxide has a maximum MAC value of 104%
Anesthetic MAC (%) Blood: Gas Coefficient @ 37'C
Nitrous Oxide 104 0.47
Desflurane 6 0.45
Sevoflurane 2 0.65
Enflurane 1.7 1.8
Isoflurane 1.4 1.4
Halothane 0.75 2.3

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Xenon:

  • The MAC value of Xenon is 71%

Option C - Desflurane:

  • The MAC value of desflurane is 6%

Option D - Halothane:

  • Halothane has a low MAC value
  • Its MAC value is 0.6%

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented to the labour room with a full-term gestation in labour pains. She wants labour analgesia. What is the gold standard method of labour analgesia selected for this patient?

choices.text: Epidural anaesthetic in combination with spinal anaesthetic
Epidural anaesthetic in combination with a general anaesthetic

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Continuous lumbar epidural:

  • Because it provides adequate analgesia in both phases of labour, continuous lumbar epidural analgesia is the most adaptable
  • The most often utilised strategy for producing labour analgesia is continuous lumbar epidural analgesia, which can give analgesia during the early stage of labour and anaesthesia for a vaginal birth or caesarean section if necessary.
  • T10-L1 sensory block is necessary during the first stage of labour for effective pain management, and S2-S4 (Pudendal nerve block) is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter inserted at the L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace affords adequate T10-S5 neural blockage.
  • Advantages of this technique:
    • No dural puncture required
    • Able to titrate the extent of sensory blockade
    • Continuous intraoperative and postoperative anaesthesia and analgesia, respectively
    • Can use in situ catheters placed for earlier administration of labour analgesia
    • No significant hemodynamic alterations in a segmental or differential blockade

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Epidural nerve block:

  • Indications for Epidural nerve block include:
  • Sole epidural anaesthetic
  • Surgeries of lower limbs, including hip, knee, and pelvic areas
  • Lower limb amputations
  • Caesarean delivery
  • Surgeries of female pelvic organs
  • Prostate and bladder surgeries
  • Lower abdominal surgeries, including appendectomy, bowel surgeries, and hernia repair

Option C - Epidural anaesthetic in combination with spinal anaesthetic:

  • This combination is referred to as a combined spinal epidural (CSE).
  • All indications noted above for sole epidural anaesthetic may also be performed with CSE.

Option D - Epidural anaesthetic in combination with a general anaesthetic:

  • Epidural analgesia combined with general anaesthesia reduces the incidence of postoperative pneumonia in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who are undergoing major abdominal surgery.
  • Indications include;
  • Penile procedures
  • Inguinal hernia repair
  • Lower limb orthopaedic procedures.
  • Thoracotomy
  • Cardiac bypass and other cardiac surgeries.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought unconscious by his neighbours with a traumatic head injury due to a road traffic accident 1 hour ago. The primary survey shows unconsciousness with a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, a temperature of 37.1 C (98.7 F), a pulse rate of 50/minute, and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. He is posted for emergency decompressive craniotomy under general anaesthesia. He is a known case of liver cirrhosis owing to Hepatitis C infection. Which one of the following intravenous anaesthetic agents is suitable for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Propofol:

  • In the above mention scenario, the patient has presented with a sustained head injury following a road traffic accident. He is a known case of liver cirrhosis, an advanced liver disease. He is posted for decompressive craniotomy. Propofol is the intravenous anaesthetic agent of choice for patients with liver disease.
  • The total body clearance of Propofol exceeds hepatic blood flow, which shows significant extrahepatic metabolism (pulmonary uptake and first-pass elimination, renal elimination). Despite rapid clearance by metabolism, there is no impairment of elimination in liver cirrhosis, and renal dysfunction also does not alter the clearance of Propofol.
  • It does not normally affect hepatic or renal function, but prolonged infusions of Propofol can cause hepatocellular injury accompanied by lactic acidosis.
  • Brady dysrhythmias and rhabdomyolysis can occur as a part of Propofol infusion syndrome.
  • Prolonged infusions result in green colour urine due to the presence of phenols in urine, but it does not alter renal function.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Etomidate:

  • Etomidate is rapidly metabolised by hydrolysis through hepatic microsomal enzymes and plasma esterases.
  • Hydrolysis is nearly complete, as only 3% of unchanged drugs are excreted in the urine.
  • The clearance is about 5 times that of thiopentone with a short elimination half-life of 2-3 hours, and etomidate does not alter hepatic and renal function tests.

Option C - Thiopentone:

  • Thiobarbiturates are metabolised in hepatocytes and, to a lesser extent, in kidneys and the central nervous system.
  • Factors affecting hepatic enzyme activity change the clearance and the hepatic enzyme induction after 2-7 days of sustained drug administration, resulting in accelerated metabolism of oral anticoagulant, phenytoin, tricyclic antidepressants, endogenous corticosteroids, bile salts, vitamin k etc.

Option D - Ketamine:

  • Ketamine is extensively metabolised by hepatic microsomal enzymes (demethylation), and its chronic administration stimulates enzymatic activity, but it does not significantly alter hepatic or renal function tests.

questions.text: A 64-year-old female was advised to get PET scan for her oncology evaluation. Which of the following is the tracer material used in PET scan?
questions.solution: 18-Flouro deoxy glucose (FDG) is glucose molecule labelled with positron emitting 18F. On administration, FDG enters inside the cell via GLUT-1 and phosphorylated by hexokinase to 18FDG phosphate. But, it can’t undergo further metabolism like glucose. Hence, it is effectively trapped inside the cell and release positrons which can be measured by radioactivity trackers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bloody diarrhea for the last 7 months. He has been taking different antibiotics without any improvement. He has no history of food allergies. On his examination, he looks pale. His stool microscopy shows numerous pus cells. Blood, stool, and urine culture are negative. His colonoscopy reveals a normal rectum along with edema, erythema, and multiple ulcerative punched-out lesions with necrotic as well as hemorrhagic surfaces being noted throughout the length of the colon in a patchy distribution. His Barium study is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulcerative Colitis

  • The barium study shown above suggests a Lead pipe appearance in the colon. It is the classical barium enema finding in chronic ulcerative colitis.

  • Other findings of Ulcerative colitis are fine mucosal granularity and pseudopolyp.

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease causing inflammation and ulcers in the digestive tract.

  • The clinical features may include:

    • Abdominal pain.

    • Bloody diarrhea.

    • Loss of appetite.

    • Weight loss.

    • Recurrent infections.

  • Ulcerative colitis is diagnosed on barium study and colonoscopy, along with a biopsy.

  • Chron's disease is another type of IBD.

  • Balsalazide, mesalamine, olsalazine, and sulfasalazine are the most effective immunosuppressants to treat ulcerative colitis.

  • Steroids are given to control the flare of ulcerative colitis.

 

Feature  Ulcerative Colitis  Crohn Disease 
Distribution  Continuous  Discontinuous (skip)
Symmetry  Symmetric  Asymmetric 
Fat halo sign location  Colon  Small bowel 
Side  Left-sided or diffuse  Right-sided or diffuse
Rectum  Involved  Often not involved 
ileocecal valve  Open  Stenosed 
Small-bowel involvement  Terminal ileum only  Any small-bowel segment 
Terminal ileum involvement  Backwash ileitis  String sign 
Fat  Perirectal fat increased  Mesenteric fat increased 
Pericolonic stranding  Rare  Frequent 
Lymph nodes  Not enlarged  Usually enlarged 
Fistulae  No  Yes 
Toxic megacolon  Yes  Yes 
Stricture  Yes  Yes 
Abscess  Yes Yes 

Option B: Crohn’s disease

  • Crohn's disease is a kind of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and the other is Ulcerative colitis.

  • investigation of choice in crohns disease is CT enterography.

  • Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the tissues in the digestive tract, mainly involving the terminal ileum and parts of the colon.

Option C: Plummer-Winson syndrome

  • It is a disorder in which there is a triage of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and dysphagia.

  • Seen in young females.

  • High risk of squamous cell carcinoma pharynx.

Option D: Chiladiti syndrome

  • Chilaiditi syndrome is a condition when pain is felt due to the transposition of a loop of the large intestine (usually transverse colon) in between the diaphragm and the liver, visible on plain abdominal X-ray or chest X-ray.

questions.text:
Assertion and reasoning-
Assertion- Barium contrast is contraindicated in bowel perforation.
Reason- Barium contrast agents may cause peritonitis if they leak into peritoneal space.

choices.text: Both the Assertion and the Reason are correct and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion.
The Assertion and the Reason are correct but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion.
OurAssertionis true but the Reason is false.
The statement of the Assertion is false but the Reason is true.

questions.solution: Barium contrast agents are not preferred in bowel perforation because of risk of peritonitis if they leak into peritoneal cavity. Low osmolar iodinated contrast agents are used in such cases.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands and her parents report that she is sensitive to sunlight. On examination, there is dry skin with hyperpigmentation and mild atrophy of the skin. Two lesions resembling basal cell carcinoma are observed on her face. Which processes are most likely to be defective in this patient?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments
Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA:

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a genetic disorder.
  • It is characterized by extreme sensitivity to sunlight.
  • Individuals with XP have a high risk of developing skin cancers at a young age.
  • This sensitivity arises from the inability to repair DNA damage caused by UV radiation.
  • UV light exposure induces the formation of pyrimidine dimers, specifically thymine dimers, in DNA.
  • Normal cells utilize the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway to recognize and remove these dimers from DNA.
  • In XP patients, mutations in genes involved in the NER pathway impair the removal of pyrimidine dimers.
  • Consequently, there is an accumulation of DNA damage.
  • This accumulation of DNA damage leads to the clinical manifestations observed in XP patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D are incorrect and the correct option has been explained above

questions.text: A 60-year-old former lifeguard presents with several small, pearly nodules on the back of her neck. A biopsy of one of the nodules (shown in the image) reveals buds of atypical, deeply-basophilic keratinocytes extending from the overlying epidermis into the papillary dermis. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
BCC is the most common malignant tumor in persons with pale skin. Although it may be locally aggressive, metastases are exceedingly rare. BCC usually develops on the sun-damaged skin of people with fair skin and freckles. The tumor is composed of nests of deeply basophilic epithelial cells with narrow rims
of cytoplasm that are attached to the epidermis and protrude into the subjacent papillary dermis. Basaloid keratinocytes are rarely seen in squamous cell carcinoma (choice D) and are not encountered in the other choices.

Diagnosis: Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 37-year-old married man presents with multiple blister-like lesions on the glans of his penis, appearing over the past 2 days. On questioning, he recalls similar episodes over the past 2 years. The examination is remarkable for tender, 3-4 mm vesicular lesions on the shaft of his penis with no apparent crusting, drainage, or bleeding. There is also slight bilateral inguinal adenopathy. During the asymptomatic period between outbreaks, where would the causative agent likely have been found?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent attacks of multiple blister-like lesions on the glans suggests genital herpes.
  • This is most often caused by HSV-2.
  • HSV are extremely widespread in the human population.
  • They are responsible for a spectrum of diseases, ranging from gingivostomatitis to keratoconjunctivitis, encephalitis, genital disease, and infections of newborns.
  • The HSVs establish latent infections in nerve cells and recurrences are common
  • During the asymptomatic period of genital herpes, sacral nerve root ganglia (S2 to S5) are the site of latency.

questions.text: A 35-years-old male came in for consultation. Previously he had a flat mole over his forearm which is of 2-4 cm in diameter. In the last few weeks there is a rapid change in size and shape of the mole. Alarmed by this sudden change, he came in for consultation. At present the lesion is still flat and with irregular borders. What is the most likely diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can, therefore arise in skin, mucosa, retina and the leptomeninges. Cutaneous melanoma is caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Its rise in incidence reflects increased recreational activity in the sun. Cumulative ultraviolet exposure favors the development of lentigo malignant melanoma and later onset of disease, whereas ‘flash fry’ exposure, typical of rapidly acquired, holiday tans, favors of other morphological variants and early onset of disease. Only 10-20% of malignant melanoma from in pre-existing nevi, with the remainder arising de novo in previously normally pigmented skin. The most likely nevi to form malignant melanoma are atypical nevi, atypical junctional lentiginous nevi (usually facial) and giant pigmented congenital nevi. Macroscopic features in a pre-existing nevus that suggest malignant change are change in size, shape, colour, thickness (elevation/ nodularity or ulceration), satellite lesions (pigment spreading into surrounding area), tingling/itching/ serosanguinous discharge (usually late signs).

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common presentation (70%) usually arising in a pre-existent nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation. Nodularity within superficial spreading melanoma heralds the onset of the vertical growth phase.

Choice B - lentigo maligna melanoma. It was previously also known as Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle. This variant presents as slow growing, variegated brown macule on the face, neck or hands of the elderly. They are positively correlated with prolonged, intense sun exposure, affecting women more than men. They account for between 5% and 10% of malignant melanoma.

Choice C - amelanotic melanoma. It may present as a flesh colored skin lesion; as a metastasis from an unknown skin primary; or in the gastrointestinal tract, with obstruction or intussusception.

Choice D - desmoplastic melanoma. It is mostly found on the head and neck region. It has a propensity for perineural infiltration and often recurs locally if not widely excised. It may be amelanotic clinically.

Learning objective Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common presentation (70%) usually arising in a pre-existent nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation.

questions.text: An 85-year-old ventilator-dependent male was endotracheally intubated 10 days ago. He remains unresponsive and is not a candidate for early extubation. The intensive care unit (ICU) attending elects to perform tracheotomy at the bedside. During the procedure, copious dark blood is encountered. This is most likely due to transection of which of the following:
questions.solution:
The anterior jugular vein can cross the mid-line overlying the proximal trachea. Midline cervical dissection without adequate visualisation can injure the vein and require open surgical repair. The other veins do not cross the midline and are not generally at risk in tracheotomy.

Schwartz 10thedpg- 565

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with complaints of hoarseness of voice for the past month. She is a biology teacher and says that due to workload, she used to take extra classes to complete the syllabus on time. On laryngoscopic examination, the findings seen are as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vocal nodule

The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and a history of occupational voice abuse (biology teacher); based on this and the laryngeal examination, she likely has vocal nodules, i.e., singer's/screamer's nodule.

  • They appear symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords, most commonly at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and the posterior 2/3rd.
  • They are caused by trauma to the vocal cords due to chronic vocal abuse, which results in edema and hemorrhage in the submucosal space, which undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.
  • The patient presents with hoarseness of voice and voice fatigue.
  • The early vocal nodule is managed conservatively by patient education against voice abuse and using the voice properly. This treatment can completely disappear many nodules.
  • For large nodules or those of persistent standing, microlaryngoscopic surgery is done.

Option B: Vocal polyp

  • Appear as unilateral and localized swelling of the membranous part of the vocal cords.
  • Appear as soft, pedunculated mass

Option C: Reinke's edema

  • Also called smoker's larynx
  • Describes the vocal cords when they become chronically and irreversibly swollen
  • Bilateral and diffuse symmetrical swelling of the whole membranous part of the vocal cords
  • Occurs due to edematous epithelial hypertrophy and polypoidal degeneration
  • Vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent appearance and prominent superficial vessels showing hyperemic and hypertrophic ventricular bands.

Option D: Vocal papilloma

  • Adult-onset papilloma usually occurs as a single, small mass that does not recur after surgical removal.
  • More common in males than females and arises at age 30-50.
  • It arises from half of the vocal cord or the anterior commissure.

questions.text: Which of the following is done in type 4 thyroplasty?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lengthened.

Type 4 Thyroplasty:

  1. Lengthening (tightening) the cord to elevate the pitch (gender transformation from male to female), for example, as a treatment of androphobia
  2. Type IV thyroplasty involves the procedure used to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cord and elevate the pitch.
  3. It converts the male character of voice to female and has been used in gender transformation.
  4. It is also used when the vocal cord is lax and bowing due to the aging process or trauma.

Option A: Medially displaced

  • Occurs in type I thyroplasty by injection of gel foam/Teflon paste.

Option B: Laterally displaced

  • Occurs in type II thyroplasty, which is done to improve the airway.

Option D: Shortened

  • Occurs in type III thyroplasty in an attempt to relax the vocal cords to lower the pitch (gender transformation from female to male).

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of hoarseness of voice for the past week. He presented 6 months ago with similar complaints with foreign body sensations. He had a 20-pack-year smoking history. After further examination, the biopsy sample was taken, which revealed glottic laryngeal carcinoma with fixation of vocal cords. Which of the following describes the staging of this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: T3

TNM STAGING OF CANCER GLOTTIS:

  • T1 - tumor confined to vocal cords with normal mobility
  • T1a -confined to one vocal cord
  • T1b -extending to both vocal cords.
  • T2 - impaired cord mobility
  • T3 - Tumor confined to larynx with vocal cord fixation.
  • T4 - Massive tumor with thyroid cartilage destruction.
  • T4a- Extension to confines of the larynx
  • T4b - Extension to the superior mediastinum, Prevertebral space, Encases carotid artery.

Option A: T1

  • T1 - The tumor is confined to vocal cords with normal mobility
  • T1a - The tumor is confined to one vocal cord
  • T1b -extending to both vocal cords

Option B: T2

  • T2 - impaired cord mobility

Option D: T4

  • T4 - Massive tumor with thyroid cartilage destruction.
  • T4a- Extension to confines of the larynx
  • T4b - Extension to the superior mediastinum, Prevertebral space, Encases carotid artery.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the hospital with difficulty swallowing for 3 weeks. He also complains of early satiety and regurgitation at night. On examination, he has bad breath. Following investigation was done for this patient. Which of the following does this X-ray demonstrate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Zenker's diverticulum

The X-ray in the image is a Barium swallow picture showing Zenker's Diverticulum/Pouch.

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through the Killian's dehiscence. Killian's dehiscence is a potential area of weakness between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.

Option B: Foreign body throat

  • Foreign body throat presents with dysphagia and drooling of saliva. It can be identified by radiography or flexible endoscopy.

Option C: Stricture in the lower esophagus

  • Lower esophageal sphincter leads to a sense of obstruction during swallowing. It usually presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. Barium swallow study can identify esophageal stricture.

Option D: Post cricoid carcinoma

  • It is associated with Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, the classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and hypopharyngeal webs.

questions.text:
A young male presents to the internal medicine OPD with the complaint of headache. He does not complaint of photophobia, nausea or vomiting. His medical history is inconsistent and he does not complain of fever. His headache is increased on bending the head. A diagnosis of frontal sinusitis is made. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the frontal sinus?


	It is located in the paired Frontal bone
	It is an unpaired sinus
	It presents at birth
	Pneumatization occurs at birth.
questions.solution:
Option A: All are incorrect

Frontal Sinus

  • Last to develop – (Early Adulthood) Present as a small cavity at birth but indistinguishable from anterior ethmoid (not present at birth).
  • Pneumatization – After 2 years.
  • Located in the frontal bone, which is unpaired, and all paranasal sinuses are paired.

Option B: Only 1 & 2

  • Frontal sinus is the paired sinuse and is located in the frontal bones

Option C: Only 1, 2, 3

  • The frontal sinuses are present in the frontal sinuses and are paired structures.
  • It is not present at the birth and is the last sinuses to develop.

Option D: Only 4

  • Pneumatization of the frontal sinuses occur after 2 years

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the outpatient department complaining of a runny nose and excessive sneezing. On further history, the patient says that he has been using xylometazoline nasal drops three times a day for the last two weeks. On examination, the nasal mucosa is swollen and erythematous in appearance. Which of the following is the correct statement(s) about his condition?

choices.text: Caused by excessive use of nasal decongestant
Avoidance of allergens may prevent it
Treatment is the use of antihistamine

questions.solution:
Option A: Caused by excessive use of  nasal decongestant

  • This patient has signs and symptoms suggestive of rhinitis medicamentosa caused by excessive use of nasal decongestants.
  • Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by excessive use of intranasal decongestants (rebound phenomenon).
  • A form of nonallergic rhinitis.
  • It is not associated with physical factors such as changes in temperature and allergens.
  • It can lead to chronic rhinosinusitis and, in severe cases, hypertrophy of turbinates.
  • Examination shows swollen and erythematous mucosa of the nose.
  • Treatment is:
    • Withdrawal of nasal decongestant drops.
    • A short course of systemic steroids should be advised.
    • Surgical resection of turbinates if hypertrophy has occurred.

Option B: Caused by steroids

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by excessive use of nasal decongestants.
  • Steroids are used to treat this condition and do not cause it.

Option C: Avoidance of allergen may prevent it

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by excessive use of nasal decongestants, not due to allergens.
  • The avoidance of allergens can prevent allergic rhinitis.

Option D: Treatment is the use of an antihistamine

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by excessive use of nasal decongestants and is treated with a short course of systemic steroids.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents in the ENT outpatient department with the complaint of foul-smelling ear discharge, fever, and severe pain in the ear. He is a known case of diabetic mellitus. On examination, there is a thick yellow-coloured discharge from the ear and granulation tissue in the canal. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Antibiotic therapy

  • The patient in the inquiry is most likely suffering from malignant otitis externa.
  • Anti-pseudomonal antibiotics are the therapy of choice.
  • Extensive surgical debridement, which was historically a necessary aspect of the therapy, is no longer required.
  • It consists of:
    • Control of diabetes.
    • Toilet of the ear canal: Remove discharge, debris, granulations, or any dead tissue or bone.
    • Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa is the most common causative agent, but sometimes other organisms can also cause this disease which can be found by culture and sensitivity.
    • Antibiotic treatment is continued for 6–8 weeks, sometimes more.

The most effective antibiotic is:

  • IV gentamicin with ticarcillin.
  • Gentamicin is both nephrotoxic and ototoxic, and ticarcillin may produce penicillin-like reactions.
  • Third-generation cephalosporins, e.g., IV ceftriaxone or IV ceftazidime, are combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • Oral Quinolones (ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, and levofloxacin) can also be effective.
  • They can be given with rifampin. Ciprofloxacin orally can be used.
  • Oral quinolones obviate the need for admission for IV injections.
  • If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should guide the surgeon.

Option A: Surgical debridement

  • Extensive surgical debridement, which was historically a necessary aspect of the therapy, is no longer required.
  • Surgical debridement in malignant otitis externa is required if the infection spreads to the base of the skull and there is an abscess of bone.

Option C: Cryotherapy

  • Cryotherapy is used to remove abnormal tissues by using extreme cold.
  • Warts and skin tags are treated by cryotherapy.
  • Cryotherapy is not associated with malignant otitis externa.

Option D: Laser removal of granulation tissue

  • Laser removal of granulation tissue is used to eliminate the infection and optimization of healing condition.
  • The granulation tissue is the pathogenic feature of chronic ear infections.
  • The granulation tissue can be treated by antibiotic therapy, surgical debridement, and a topical steroid.

questions.text: A fifty year old man with type-I diabetes is referred to an ophthalmologist for evaluation of developing cataract. Which of the following enzyme is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?
questions.solution: Aldose reductase is a general enzyme which can reduce any aldehyde sugar. This enzyme is the first enzyme of Sorbitol Pathway. When excess glucose is present in diabetics, then this enzyme converts Glucose to Sorbitol, which is responsible for Snow Flake Cataract.

questions.text: A fifty-year-old man came to your clinic complaining of decreased and blurry vision in his left eye. He also says that he has a white circle in his eye. A diagnosis of cataract is made, and you schedule surgery for its removal. During surgery, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery occurs. The surgery is immediately terminated, and the patient is admitted for further evaluation. Which of the following is not true regarding this complication?

choices.text: Bleeding from short posterior ciliary artery into suprachoroidal space

questions.solution:
• The correct answer is

  • Option D. Self resolving: While some complications of ocular surgery can resolve on their own, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery leading to bleeding and associated complications would typically require prompt medical intervention to manage the consequences, such as controlling intraocular pressure and addressing potential complications like suprachoroidal hemorrhage.

  • Here's an explanation of the options:

    Option A. Shallowing of anterior chamber: This can occur due to leakage of intraocular contents, leading to a shallow anterior chamber.

    Option B. Expulsion of intraocular contents: Rupture of the posterior ciliary artery can lead to increased intraocular pressure and expulsion of intraocular contents.

    Option C. Bleeding from short posterior ciliary artery into suprachoroidal space: This is the likely mechanism in this scenario. The short posterior ciliary arteries supply blood to the choroid, and rupture can cause bleeding into the suprachoroidal space, leading to various complications, including shallow anterior chamber and expulsion of intraocular contents.

    d. Self-resolving: While some complications of ocular surgery can resolve on their own, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery leading to bleeding and associated complications would typically require prompt medical intervention to manage the consequences, such as controlling intraocular pressure and addressing potential complications like suprachoroidal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented with complaints of visual disturbance of the left eye. Clinical findings revealed pterygium. Which of the following is true about pterygium?

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Pterygium

  • Wing shapes fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from the either side
  • Etiology – hot climates
  • Degenerative & hyperplastic condition of conjunctiva

Symptoms

  • Visual disturbance (astigmatism)
  • Cosmetic intolerance Sign
  • Triangular fold of conjunctiva mainly on nasal side
  • Stocker line – iron deposition on corneal epithelium

Rx

  • Surgical excision-recurrence chance is 30-50 %
  • Best RX- Surgical excision with free conjunctival autograft taken from the same eye or other

questions.text: The human eyes are the most complicated sense organs in the human body. Every part of the human eye is responsible for a certain action, from the muscles and tissues to nerves and blood vessels. Which of the following is known as the dangerous zone of the eye?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ciliary body

  • The ciliary body is called the dangerous area of the eye.
  • The allergic theory is postulated as the reason for calling it a dangerous eye area.
  • During trauma to the eye, when the ciliary body is injured, it exposes uveal pigments which act as the allergen, leading to plastic uveitis in the good eye.

Option A: Sclera

  • The sclera is the tough layer of the eye.
  • It is not a dangerous area of the eye.

Option B: Retina

  • The retina is present at the posterior surface of the eye
  • Its injury does not expose the eye to the hidden allergen.

Option C: Optic nerve

  • Optic nerve injury results in loss of unilateral vision.
  • However, it is not a dangerous area of the eye.

questions.text: The national plan of action of the Government of India focuses on under-served areas with an emphasis on community participation. It facilitates the formation of state-level Vision 2020- plans of action and programmes led by the state governments, along with intensive input from local and international NGOs. According to the Indian version of Vision 2020, which of the following diseases is not included?
questions.solution:
Option D: Onchocerciasis

  • Onchocerciasis is absent in India. Therefore, it is not included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by the WHO.
  • 'Vision 2020: The Right to Sight',10 is a global initiative launched by WHO in Geneva on Feb. 18, 1999, in a broad coalition with a 'Task Force of International Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) to combat the massive problem of blindness in the world.
  • The objective of Vision 2020:

This new global initiative aims to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020 and to reduce the global burden of blindness, which currently affects an estimated 45 million people worldwide.

  • Strategic approaches of Vision 2020: Right to Sight (Global perspective) are:
    • Disease prevention and control,
    • Training of eye health personnel,
    • Strengthening of existing eye care infrastructure,
    • Use of appropriate and affordable technology, and
    • Mobilisation of resources.
  • Disease prevention and control: Globally, WHO has identified five major blinding eye conditions for immediate attention to achieve the goals of Vision 2020, which are:
    • Cataract
    • Childhood blindness
    • Trachoma
    • Refractive errors and low vision
    • Onchocerciasis
  • These conditions have been chosen based on their contribution to the burden of blindness, feasibility and affordability of interventions to control them.
  • Each country will decide its priorities based on the magnitude of specific blinding conditions in that country.

Option A: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy is considered in place of onchocerciasis in the Indian version of the right to sight.

Option B: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma has been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

Option C: Refractive error

  • Refractive errors and low vision have been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

questions.text: VISION 2020: The Right to Sight (V2020) is a global program that was established in partnership in 1999 with the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) and the World Health Organization (WHO) with the joint goal of eliminating avoidable blindness by 2020. Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO does not target which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Option C: Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis

  • The epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is not included in the Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.
  • Vision 2020

    • Aim →20/20 by 2020 → 20 feet/20feet = 6 metres/6metres by 2020, by eliminating:

  1. Cataract → by surgery
  2. Trachoma → by SAFE strategy
  3. Childhood blindness → by vitamin A supplementation
  4. Refractive error → by spectacle correction
  5. Onchocerciasis → not a problem in India (In India, we consider instead of onchocerciasis
  6. GLAUCOMA
  7. DIABETICTIC RETINOPATHY  

Option A: Cataract

  • A cataract is the major cause of preventable blindness. 

  • It is included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

Option B: Trachoma

  • Trachoma is caused by chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It is a preventable cause of blindness in low socioeconomic areas where chlamydia infections are highest.

  • It is included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

Option D: Onchocerciasis

  • The parasite Onchocerciasis causes Onchocerca volvulus.

  • It causes river blindness.

  • It is prevented by ivermectin.

questions.text: A 33-yr-old male presented to your clinic with numbness from the lower trunk to the distal lower extremities, anteriorly and posteriorly, bilaterally equal. On examination, reflexes were hyperactive, and hypoesthesia was present with the neurological pinwheel exam. Initial investigations were done. A probable diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis was made. Which of the following tests is not useful for evaluating the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Electronystagmogram

  • Electronystomogram is not used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
  • It is used in patients with problems of vertigo and balance problems.
  • It helps in the diagnosis of Meniere's disease

Investigation of multiple sclerosis

  • Evoked Potentials 
  • E.P. marked delay in the latency of a specific E.P. component (as opposed to a reduced amplitude or distorted wave shape) is suggestive of demyelination
  • Cerebrospinal Fluid 
  • CSF abnormalities found in M.S. include a mononuclear cell pleocytosis
  • Increased level of intrathecally synthesized IgG.Oligoclonal bands
  • The total CSF protein is usually normal or mildly elevated.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging 
  • Lesions are frequently oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface, corresponding to the pathologic pattern of perivenous demyelination (Dawson's fingers).
  • Lesions are multifocal within the brain, brainstem, and spinal cord.

​​​​​​​

  • MRI figure showing periventricular plaques characteristic of multiple sclerosis

Option A: Lumbar puncture

  • Lumbar puncture is done for CSF, which is crucial for diagnosis as it shows oligoclonal bands characteristic of M.S.

Option B: Gadolinium-enhanced MRI

  • MRI is the first line of investigation for M.S., and it shows periventricular plaques

​​​​​​​Option C: Visual evoked potential

  • Visual evoked potential can help in diagnosing M.S. as it can detect the abnormalities in the nerves

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with pathological fractures of the clavicle and ribs. X-ray shows periosteal resorption of second and third metatarsals and phalanges. Urinary and serum calcium levels are raised. The doctor decided to send her for a radionuclide scan of the parathyroid gland. Which of the following finding can be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hot spots:

  • Tc-99m-sestamibi is a radiopharmaceutical that is taken up by cells with a high concentration of mitochondria
  • It is a highly cellular/metabolically active tissue such as the myocardium of the heart.
  • But also abnormal tissues such as oxyphil cell parathyroid adenomas, myeloma, and breast cancer (the basis of so-called scintimammography).
  • Tc99m-sestamibi is absorbed faster by a hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland than by a normal parathyroid gland.
  • This is dependent on several histologic features within the abnormal parathyroid gland itself.
  • The hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland will take up more of the Tc99m-sestamibi and show up 'brighter' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures. These are known as hot spots.
  • The hypo-functioning parathyroid gland will take up less of the Tc99m-sestamibi and show up 'darker' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures. These are known as cold spots.
  • This patient presents with signs of hyperparathyroidism, which suggests a parathyroid adenoma.

Therefore, a parathyroid adenoma will be a hot spot on a parathyroid scan.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cold spots:

  • The hypo-functioning parathyroid gland takes up less of the Tc99m-sestamibi and will show up 'darker' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures.
  • These are known as cold spots.

 

Option C - Panda sign:

  • The 'panda sign' is a 67Ga scan finding caused by bilateral involvement of the parotid and lacrimal glands due to sarcoidosis combined with normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

 

Option D - Hawkin’s sign:

  • The Hawkins sign can be seen on anteroposterior ankle radiographs 6–8 weeks after a vertical fracture of the neck of the talus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with his wife and presents with acute onset of severe pain in his right great toe. He has long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On physical examination, inflammation and erythema of the affected joint are visible. On x-ray, rat bite erosions with overhanging edges are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Gouty arthritis

  • Patient with arthritis due to gout often presents with swollen, red, and painful asymmetric joints.
  • Risk factors of gout include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, chronic alcohol use, and dyslipidemia.
  • A painful metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the classical manifestation of gouty arthritis.
  • Tophus formation often occurs on the olecranon bursa, Achilles tendon, and external ear.
  • Radiographically, the typical finding of gout is a punched-out lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin and overhanging edge, defined as the "Martel sign" or "rat-bite" erosion.

 

Figure: Gouty arthritis

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • The radiographic hallmarks of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, joint space narrowing and marginal erosions.

 

Option C: Osteoarthritis

  • The radiographic findings of primary osteoarthritis are-
    • Nonuniform loss of joint spaces
    • Osteophyte formation
    • Cyst formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis.
  • The radiographs of an initial stage of osteoarthritis may not show all of the findings

 

Option D: Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • Radiographic findings of ankylosing spondylitis are bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis (earliest feature), bamboo-spine (knobby spine, poker back or universal syndesmophytes), syndesmophytes, and enthesitis.

questions.text: A 6 year old girl is brought to spine clinic by her parents. The patient on examination is revealed to have an abnormal sideways bend in the spine. The doctor wants to use a brace to correct the said condition. Which of the following CAN’T be used?
questions.solution:
All braces are used for scoliosis curve correction. ASH brave is used in thoracic vertebral collapse eg in trauma or in TB spine.

Learning Objectives : one should know what braces can be used for what condition. Out of a plethora or orthotics, a surgeon should make the best choice.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with complaints of cough & shortness of breath. Initial investigations were done. HRCT revealed features consistent with the diagnosis of Mucormycosis. Which of the following is/are the cause(s) of the said diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucormycosis is caused by zygomycetes family which is characterized by aseptate & obtuse angled hyphae

This family includes:-

  1. Rhizopus
  2. Mucor
  3. Absidia
  • Mucormycosis is also known as zygomycosis
  • Mucor infection is very common in patients of diabetes mellitus and patients having frequent blood transfusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the hospital with a high fever, chills, inflammation of lymphatic vessels, and swollen lymph nodes. On physical examination, the left leg of the patient was swollen with thickened skin. The clinical diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis was made by the physician. All of the following statements are true regarding Lymphatic Filariasis except?

choices.text: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus
Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

questions.solution:
Option B: Intermediate host – Man

  • The intermediate host in lymphatic filariasis is Mosquito.
  • Man is the Definitive host.

Option A: Causative agent – Wuchereria bancrofti

  • The causative agent of lymphatic filariasis is Wuchereria bancrofti.

Option C: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus

  • Main vector in India is Culex quinquefasciatus.

Option D: Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

  • Thick film preparation is the most common epidemiological method for detection.

questions.text: DNA can be transferred from one bacterium to another by a number of processes. Uptake by a recipient cell of soluble DNA released from a donor cells is defined as which one of the following?
questions.solution:
1. Acquisition of soluble DNA from environment and incorporation in its genome is called transformation.
  2. First demonstrated in S. pneumoniae by Griffith 1928. DNA must be derived from closely related strain
  3. Cells that can take up naked DNA are called as competent
  4. Transformation can be inhibited by DNAases

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought in with history of chronic diarrhea for the past 2 years. Initial investigations revealed no abnormalities. Further evaluation revealed it to be cause of Giardia. This recurrent Giardiasis can be associated with?
questions.solution: Common variable immunodeficiency is associated with recurrent giardiasis.

questions.text: A6-year-old boy was presented with a history of intermittent fever and constipation for 7 days which progressed to vomiting, neck pain, myalgias, and headache for 2 days. Initial investigations were done. The physician suspected it as a cause of enteric origin. For isolation of Salmonella,Wilson and Blair is used. Which type of medium is Wilson -Blair medium?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair is a selective medium for Salmonella.

It contains an indicator bismuth sulphite that gets converted into bismuth sulphide as a result of the hydrogen sulphide produced by the Salmonella.

The color of the colonies on this medium is black.

questions.text: A 35 years old patient complains of abdominal cramps along with profuse diarrhea. The treating physician wants to process the stool culture for isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the media is best choice for stool culture?

choices.text: Culture on TCBS medium and incubated at 37º C under aerobic conditions
Culture on Skirrow medium and incubated at 42 ºC under microaerobic conditions
Culture on MacConkey medium and incubated at 42º C under aerobic conditions
Culture on Wilson & Blair medium and incubated at 37º C under microaerobic conditions

questions.solution:
Option 2

Selective media (Butzler medium, Skirrow’s medium, Preston’s Campylobacter selective medium, and Blaser’s medium) are needed, and incubation must be in an atmosphere with reduced O2 (5% O2) with added CO2 (10% CO2).

→ Incubation of primary plates for isolation of C. jejuni should be at 42°C.
  • TCBS (selective) medium is used for V. cholerae
  • MacConkey agar (indicator or differential media) It differentiate LF bacteria from NLF bacteria.
  • Wilson Blair bismuth sulphite medium: It is used for isolation of Salmonella Typhi.

questions.text:

Most common worm infestation in India

questions.text: Active immunization is considered as the induction of immunity after exposure to an antigen. All of the following can result in active immunity except:
questions.solution:
Adaptive immunity is of 4 types

  • Natural active (associated with infections)
  • Natural passive (from Mother to child through placenta or breast feeding)
  • Artificial active (Vaccination)
  • Artificial Passive through immunoglobin transfer

So correct option is ‘c’ in which active immunity is Not acquired through Immunoglobin transfer.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with complaints of watery diarrhea & abdominal cramps. The causative organism Clostridium perfringens was identified by the test as shown below.aIdentify the test?

choices.text: Example of agar diffusion in 2 dimensions
Demonstration of Swarming of C. perfringens

questions.solution:
The above test is Nagler reaction which is aNeutralization test .

Reactions of Clostridium perfringens:

1. Nagler reaction : It is a biochemical test used toidentify organisms (Eg: Clostridium perfringens) that liberate phospholipases (lecithinases). Bacterial lecithinase break down the lecithin (a normal component of egg yolk) to insoluble diglycerides resulting in an opaque halo.

Procedure:

  • The media used isEgg yolk mediumwhere Clostridium is inoculated in two streaks (one is of test organism and other is control organism).
  • On one half of the culture plate anti-toxin is added , on the another half there is no antitoxin.
  • Neutralization occurs between antitoxin and α lecithinase toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens.
  • An opalescent halo is formed around colonies that produce lecithinase (clostridial α-toxin).

2. Target haemolysis : Double zone haemolysis (Refer to the image below).

Inner zone: due to the theta toxin

Outer zone: due toalphatoxin.

3.Stormy fermentation in litmus milk.

4.Reverse CAMP test.(Image below)

questions.text: The introduction lecture on modern microbiology lab microbiologists tells about the electron microscope that which is a microscope that uses a beam of accelerated electrons as a source of illumination. It is used to investigate inorganic specimens, including microorganisms and macromolecules. Who is the founder of the Electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ernst Ruska

  • Ernst August Friedrich Ruska was born on 25 December 1906 and died on 27 May 1988.
  • He was a german physicist who won the Nobel prize in physics in 1986 for his work in electron optics, including designing the first electron microscope.

Electron microscope:

  • A beam of electrons used instead of a Light beam focused by circular magnets instead of a lens object is held in the path of beam scatters the electrons by object image is formed on fluorescent viewing screen maximum resolution can obtain [0.2nm-0.5nm] (100 times better than light microscope) vacuum is used.

Option A: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek

  •  Father of microscopy.
  • The first person to observe and describe microorganisms accurately was amateur microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek (1632–1723).
  • He coined the term " Little Animalcules" For microorganisms.

Option C: Robert Koch:

  • Father of modern microbiology.
  • Proposed KOCH POSTULATES.
  • Discovered TB and cholera bacilli.
  • Proposed hanging drop method, aniline dye staining, and solid media concept.

Note: Bacteria that do not follow KOCH postulates are Mycobacterium leprae and Treponema pallidum.

Option D: Louis Pasteur:

  • Father of microbiology.
  • Proposed fermentation principle.
  • Disapproved abiogenesis theory.
  • Proposed germ theory, autoclave & hot air oven, and pasteurization of milk.
  • Vaccines:
    • C → Cholera
    • A → Anthrax
    • R → Rabies

questions.text: To control the bleeding from carotid artery, the surgeon can compress the carotid artery against the anterior tubercle of which of the following vertebrae?

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient was referred by the family doctor to a tertiary Hospital. Patient had a complaint severe abdominal pain. His ultrasonography couldn’t find any abnormalities. He was advised for a gastro endoscopy by his surgeon on next day.
