His endoscopic study showed an early invasive cancer and the oncologists suggested for a total gastrectomy. The patient was advised for a lifelong supplementation of?
questions.solution:
Stomach performs a number of functions. Absorption of Vitamin B12, it needs intrinsic factors secreted from parietal cells. Patients with total gastrectomy done has to get lifelong supplementation of Vitamin B12 parenterally.

The ingested food is first stored in the stomach. Since, total gastrectomy has done it can lead to the bolus syndrome. Bolus syndrome characterized by nausea, sweating, loose stools etc.

Enzymes produced in stomach, has got a lot of functions such as maintaining the pH, digestion etc.

Option A and D : Whether gastrectomy done or not supplementation of gastric enzymes and HCl is necessary for all the people. Digestion and absorption of proteins can take place in the absence of pepsin which is produced from chief cells.

Option C : Short chain fatty acids are absorbed in stomach and most of the fat is absorbed in the small intestine. In gastrectomy patient’s fat-soluble vitamins will be absorbed along with dietary fats.

Educational objective : Patients with gastrectomy done has to get lifelong supplementation of Vitamin B12 due to poor absorption that occurs with the deficiency of intrinsic factors. Deficiency of intrinsic factors can lead to megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension was diagnosed with Lymphangiosarcoma. Which of the following is the most common site for lymphangiosarcoma? is :
questions.solution: Most cases arise from lymphedema induced by a radical mastectomy in breast cancer patients with an average onset of 5 - 15 years and an occurrence rate of <1%. Although there has also been significant reports regarding development from Milroy lymphedema and in idiopathic, congenital, traumatic, or filarial lymphedema.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman complains of anal itching and burning. Physical examination reveals an erythematous, scaly lesion, 3 cm in circumference, within the anal canal. The intersphincteric groove can not be appreciated in the area of the lesion. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Appropriate initial management includes which of the following?

choices.text: Metronidazole 250 mg PO QID for 14 days

questions.solution:
Extramammary Paget’s disease may be found in the axilla and in the anogenital region, including the labia majora, penis, scrotum, groin, pubic area, perineum, perianal region, thigh, and buttock. Paget’s disease of the perianal area is a malignant neoplasm of the intraepidermal portion of apocrine glands with or without associated dermal involvement. Paget’s disease has a long preinvasive phase, but if untreated, an invasive adenocarcinoma of the apocrine gland type develops. The disease is more common in women than men, with the highest incidence in the seventh decade.

Macroscopically, the lesion appears as an erythematous scaly or eczematoid plaque-like lesion, similar to other benign perianal lesions, making clinical diagnosis difficult. A definite diagnosis is made by biopsy, which shows characteristic histologic appearance—large, pale, vacuolated cells with hyperchromatic eccentric nuclei. The cells invariably contain acid mucosubstances, an important feature in distinguishing this lesion from melanoma and Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: You are a third-year resident in the surgery department. During a sphincterotomy procedure for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, the chief surgeon passes on the surgical blade to you and tells you to continue the procedure. To minimize the chance of pancreatic duct injury during surgery, you should make the incision at which of the following positions in the ampulla?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11 o’clock position

  • Sphincterotomy is performed from 10 to 11 o’clock position. 
  • Placing the incision at this location in the ampulla minimizes the chance of pancreatic duct injury, which is generally located opposite the planned sphincterotomy site.

Option A: 3 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 3 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option B: 6 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 6 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option C: 9 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 9 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

questions.text: A 69-year-old well-controlled, hypertensive man was seen in ER with 3-month history of mild headache and sudden onset of hemiparesis. On examination, he exhibit mild dysphasia and lethargy. His cognitive function testing indicates moderate diminution of his recent memory and executive function. His hemiparesis is more dense in arm and leg and is mild in his face.CT scan without contrast demonstrates a 3-cm irregular hemorrhage surrounded by marked edema and mass effect in frontal-temporal region. The most likely cause of bleed is?
questions.solution: History of recent onset of headache in adult should always raise the suspicion of neoplasm. Amyloid angiopathy and hypertension are frequent cause of the intracerebral hemorrhage in elderly, but the critical difference with neoplastic bleed is the presence of edema and mass effect which is disproportionate to the size of the hemorrhage. The presence of edema suggests a preexisting lesion with recent bleed. Although intraparenchymal hemorrhage can produce edema but it takes many hours to develop. Therefore, the presence of edema in early hours after the ictus is indicative of underlying pathology. AVMs and coagu-lopathies also can cause intraparenchymal bleed without surrounding edema which is the hallmark of an underlying lesion.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of dyspnoea, chest retrosternal pain and epigastric pain. Chest x-ray showed a large left pleural effusion . A CT scan was performed and revealed pneumomediastinum, left collapsed lung and loculated pleural effusion. A probable diagnosis of Boerrhave syndrome was made. The said diagnosis is due to:
questions.solution:
BOERHAAVE’S SYNDROME

  • Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus into the left pleural cavity or just above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • These patients are typically male (85%), 40 to 60 years of age, who have a history of recent emesis.

Clinical features

  • Mackler’s triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema is seen in spontaneous esophageal perforation.
  • Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain.
  • Mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, but early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is noted in only 20% or less of patients.
  • Fever and sepsis develop with increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities.
  • Patients with an abdominal perforation have epigastric abdominal pain that is also often referred to the back and left shoulder.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as the initial therapy of documented deep venous thrombosis in a post-operative case?
questions.solution:
Antithrombotic therapy in DVT

  • Any venous thrombosis involving the femoropopliteal system is treated with full anticoagulation ·
  • Traditionally, the treatment of DVT centers around heparin treatment to maintain the PTT at 60 to 80 seconds, followed by warfarin therapy to obtain an INR of 2.5 to 3.0.
  • This initial therapy usually is continued for at least 5 days, while oral vitamin K antagonists are being simultaneously administered.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted to your hospital with recurrent upper abdominal pain for one year. The patient also had presented with diabetes/glucose intolerance, steatorrhea, gallstones, and achlorhydria.. Computed tomography (CT) indicated an isodense mass of 8.4 cm×3.7 cm in the body and tail of the pancreas with notable enhancement. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Somatostatinoma

  • Gallstones are associated with somatostatinoma.
  • Somatostatinoma:
    • Somatostatinoma syndrome is a triad of diabetes mellitus, steatorrhea, and gallstones, but it also includes weight loss and hypochlorhydria.
    • Because somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions, patients with a somatostatinoma present with gallstones due to bile stasis, diabetes due to inhibition of insulin secretion, and steatorrhea due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion
    • Most somatostatinomas originate in the proximal pancreas or the pancreatoduodenal groove, with the ampulla and periampullary area as the most common site (60%)
    • The most common presentations are abdominal pain, jaundice, and cholelithiasis. Of tumours, >70% are malignant, with metastasis to the liver or lymph nodes commonly noted at the time of diagnosis. They are rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome but are associated with Von Recklinghausen disease and pheochromocytoma.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum somatostatin levels.
    • Treatment involves complete excision of the tumour and cholecystectomy if there is no metastatic disease

Other options

Option A: Insulinoma

  • Insulinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasms and present with a typical clinical syndrome known as Whipple’s triad.
  • Whipple's triad: fasting hypoglycemia (<50 mg/dL or <2.7 mmol/L) symptoms of hypoglycemia. immediate relief of symptoms after the administration of intravenous glucose. 
  • The majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and 10% are malignant. They are typically cured by simple enucleation.
  • Approximately 90% of insulinomas are sporadic, and 10% are associated with MEN1 syndrome.

Option B: VIPoma

  • Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide Secreting Tumour (VIPoma) syndrome, also called WDHA (Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) syndrome. This syndrome was described by Verner and Morrison. They are most commonly located in the distal pancreas.

Option D: Glucagonoma

  • Diabetes in association with dermatitis should raise the suspicion of a glucagonoma. The classic necrolytic migratory erythema (due to low levels of amino acids) manifests as cyclic migrations of lesions with spreading margins and healing centres typically on the lower abdomen, perineum, perioral area and feet. Patients also complain of an enlarged sensitive tongue.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels. They are more often in the body and tail of the pancreas.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male underwent a laparoscopic right-sided hemicolectomy because of colon carcinoma, under general (propofol-based) anaesthesia in combination with epidural anaesthesia. The surgery was successful, and patient recovery was excellent according to the Early Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol. On arrival at the ward, the patient was hesitant to discuss penile complaints with attending female nurses. After 1 day of persistent painful erections, the patient notified the treating physician. On close inspection, painful engorgement of the penis in absence of sexual arousal was observed. All of the following statements are correct about this condition except?

choices.text: High flow priapism occurs secondary to penile or perineal trauma
Low flow priapism can lead to compartment syndrome
Winter’s procedure is percutaneous cavernoglandular shunt for priapism

questions.solution:
Answer is 3 as mainly diagnosis is done clinically .

PRIAPISM

  • Persistent painful erection in absence of sexual excitement / desire or it persist after sexual excitement / desire
    • Min duration of painful erection – 24 hours
    • It is an emergency & delay in treatment leads to Cavernosal fibrosis & impotence
    • It should be treated within 6 hours to prevent other complications
    • Priapism is of 2 types
High Flow Low Flow (MC)
  • Non- Ischemic

Causes

  • Penile Trauma
  • Perineal trauma
  • Due to formation of arterial sinusoidal shunts.
  • Ischemic

Causes

  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Leukemia
  • Fat emboli
  • Spinal cord lesion
  • Malignant Penile inflammation
  • Trazadone Injection

Clinical Presentation

  • In children (5 – 10 years) with sickle cell disease - Painful erection during nights
  • In Adults – iatrogenic

Diagnosis

  • Mainly clinical
  • Doppler is helpful in diagnosis

Treatment

  • If patient comes within 4-6 hrs.- ketamine injection given (> 50% cases improve)

↓ No improvement

Aspiration & saline irrigation

↓ No improvement

Hyaluronidase injection

  • For High flow priapism – Selective internal Pudendal Angiography f/b embolization of feeding vessel.

Another surgical option - Shunts [Blood is shunted from corpora cavernosa]

  • Corporo-glanular shunt – Winter shunt
  • Corporo-spongiosal Shunt – QUACKEL or SACHER shunt
  • Corporo–saphenous shunt – GRAYHACK shunt
  • Corporo-dorsal vein shunt – BARRY shunt

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with acute pancreatitis complaints of recurrent episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemoglobin of 5.8 gm/dL, requiring transfusions of red cell units. Gastroscopy showed diffuse fundal gastric varices but no esophageal varices. A CT scan showed liquefactive necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma and splenomegaly with diffuse varices around the gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligament. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Splenectomy

  • Acute pancreatitis can cause splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery.
  • This aneurysm causes splenomegaly.
  • Splenomegaly causes gastric varices, mainly along the greater curvature of the stomach and fundus.
  • Left-sided portal hypertension is also called SINISTRAL hypertension.
  • The treatment of choice is Splenectomy.

Option B: Portocaval shunt

  • The portocaval shunt is an abnormal vein connecting the blood supply from the intestine to the vein that returns blood to the heart, bypassing the liver, which is called shunting.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient has a problem with the spleen, so a Splenectomy should be done.

Option C: Splenorenal shunt

  • This is the surgical process in which the splenic vein is detached from the portal vein and reattached to the left kidney vein, called the renal vein, to relieve pressure, causing a portal system shunt.
  • The first line of treatment is surgical splenectomy to decompress the left portal venous system in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient underwent total thyroidectomy. After surgery patient complained of inability to raise her voice pitch. The most likely cause is injury to:

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve givessensory supplyto the larynx andabove the level of true vocal cord.

  • All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx aresupplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid (which is supplied by superior laryngeal, which is a branch of external laryngeal nerve).
  • Since cricothyroid is a tensor of the VC, so theVC will be curved/bowed and floppy leading to weak and husky voice and inability to raise the pitch.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dysphagia and hematemesis. Dysphagia affects more solids than liquids. An endoscopic evaluation reveals a mass lesion in the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following options is most likely associated with tumorsof the gastroesophageal junction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Siewert type II:

  • Siewert classification is a system of anatomical classification used for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction.
  • In type Siewert type II, Adenocarcinomais present in the real cardia.
  • Its exact location is 1 cm above and 2 cm below the gastroesophageal junction add often called junctional carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect and explained in LO.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about insulinoma?

choices.text: Tumor of pancreatic β cells which results in overproduction of insulin and can cause hypoglycemia.
Symptomatic patients have low blood glucose and increased C-peptide levels.
More than 90 % of cases are associated with MEN 1 syndrome
Whipple triad: low blood glucose, symptoms of hypoglycemia (eg, lethargy, diplopia), and resolution of symptoms after normalization of glucose levels may be seen.

questions.solution:
(More than 90 % of cases are associated with MEN 1 syndrome)

Correct statement would be → ∼ 10% of cases associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

A, B and D are true about insulinoma. Therefore, are not the answer

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Insulinoma is the Tumor of pancreatic β cells which results in overproduction of insulin and causes hypoglycemia. May see Whipple triad: low blood glucose, symptoms of hypoglycemia (eg, lethargy, syncope, diplopia), and resolution of symptoms after normalization of glucose levels. Symptomatic patients have decreased blood glucose and Increased C-peptide levels (vs exogenous insulin use). ∼ 10% of cases associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

Treatment: surgical resection.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male worker was brought in to the emergency department by his company supervisor with a history of accidental amputation of right ring finger. After the first aid & stabilizing the patient, you are referring the patient to a higher center for plastic surgeon opinion & further management. The amputated finger is transported in:-
questions.solution: “if it is anticipated that the amputated part will be considered for replantation, it is critical to transport the patient and the part in an appropriate manner. The amputated part is placed in a clean, dry, plastic bag, which is sealed and placed on top of ice in a Styrofoam container. This keeps the part sufficiently cool at 4 degree C to 10 degree C without freezing. The amputated part is wrapped in a lightly moistened saline gauze to prevent tissue drying. (Schwartz 20/e p 1996)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with complaints of epigastric pain for 5 days came to our emergency department for help. Physical examination showed right lower quadrant tenderness without muscle guarding and rebounding pain. CT- abdomen showed suspect MD in the distal ileum and enteritis at the ileum. Which of the following is not a recognized complication of a Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the most common congenital abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract occurring in 2% of the population. It is an embryological remnant of the vitello-intestinal duct and is therefore found within 2 ft of the ileocaecal valve. The diverticulum varies in size in different individuals; large diverticula often have a fibrous cord (the remnant duct) linking them to the umbilicus.

The cells that line the vitello-intestinal duct are pluripotent and may therefore differentiate into any tissue. However, most commonly the diverticulum is lined with heterotrophic gastric epithelium (50%) or pancreatic tissue (5%). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's is gastrointestinal haemorrhage secondary to peptic ulcer-ation of this abnormal gastric epithelium, which contains a pre-dominance of acid-secreting parietal cells. This is most commonly a childhood presentation causing melaena at around 10 years of age and accounts for over 50% of all symptomatic disease associated with Meckel's. The mucosa is also at risk of malignant change, most com-monly adenocarcinoma.

Meckel's diverticula are at risk of mechanical complications. Diver-ticulitis accounts for 20% of symptomatic presentations with features indistinguishable from acute appendicitis. The abnormal segment is also liable to cause intussusceptions following inversion into the ileum or volvulus caused by the small bowel twisting around on the fibrous band at the diverticulum apex. Other presentations include perforation and umbilical fistulation, which occurs when the entire vitello-­intestinal duct remains patent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male tracheostomised patient, with portex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. Which of the following is best next step in the management?

choices.text: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube
Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

questions.solution:
Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube is best next step in the management in the above case

  • Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate is done to avoid the blockage.
  • Suction of the tube with saline can’t be used when there’s a complete obstruction.
  • Jet ventilation is done below the level of larynx, when we’re operating on the larynx.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought in by her mother with a complaint of left-sided anterior neck swelling for 1 week. Her mother states that the swelling is painful and has progressively increased in size over the past week, which is associated with difficulty swallowing. She has a fever of 100° F, a pulse rate of 100 bpm, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute. She has a history of being treated for an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) a week ago. On examination, there is no hoarseness, difficulty breathing.. Which one of the following statements is correct about the given condition?

choices.text: Most common cause is the presence of pyriform sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The most common cause is the presence of pyriform sinus:

  • In the case discussed above, the child has features of neck swelling following an upper respiratory tract infection one week ago. In this case, the diagnosis is suppurative thyroiditis.
  • It is more common in children and is marked by the presence of a pyriform sinus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - More common in adults:

  • It is more common in children than adults because of the persistent pyriform sinus (the connection between the oropharynx and thyroid).

Option C - Most common organism: legionella:

  • The most common organism that causes acute suppurative thyroiditis is either Staphylococcus aureus or streptococci.

Option D - Most patients are managed conservatively:

  • Patients with acute suppurative thyroiditis are not managed conservatively.
  • The treatment includes incision, drainage, and a suitable antibiotic sensitive to the causative organism.

questions.text: 50-year-old Kim was having coffee in a cafe. After his coffee, he was feeling severe pain in his right leg. His vitals were checked and the blood pressure was 145/91mmHg, saturation was 95% and PR 87bpm. He has a history of smoking one packet daily for the last 30 years. No known previous history of hospitalization and diseases. Physical examination reveals that he got a pitting edema on his right leg extending upto the knee. His peripheral pulses all were symmetrical and full. He was admitted in the hospital and he was started with medications for prolonging activated partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time in a dose dependent manner. But this caused no any effect in thrombin time. Which of the following agent would have been given to the patient for relief?
questions.solution:
The patient will be likely having a deep vein thrombosis. Heparin is required for the treatment of DVT, which can bind with the antithrombin III. Usually more than or equal to 3 therapies are needed to prevent the further thrombosis which will occur in the future. Drugs working on the extrinsic pathway will make the prothrombin time while drugs acting on the intrinsic pathway will be prolonging the aPTT. Factor Xa is a common factor for both the pathways. Heparin and other inhibitory drugs can prolong the thrombin time.

The main drug of choice for deep vein thrombosis is Vitamin K inhibitors such as Warfarin, direct factor Xa inhibitors such as Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Idraparinux, low molecular weight heparin and direct thrombin inhibitors such as Argatroban, Dabigatran. Among all these, direct factor Xa inhibitors are more specific that they will be inhibiting only Factor Xa.

Option A : They will be still in development. They will be working on the extrinsic pathway of coagulation cascade. As it works on the extrinsic pathway, PT will be getting prolonged than the aPTT and TT.

Option C : Direct thrombin inhibitors, they can prevent thrombin formation, which can lead to the formation of a new clot. They can make the TT longer with minimal activity on the aPTT or PT.

Option D : This can bind with the AT III. And will promote its action to bind with the factor Xa. This can make the aPTT to have longer duration. Heparin got a pentasacchride chain and it consist of more than 18 units. Thrombin also get bind with unfractionated heparin - AT III complex and it can also prolong TT.

Educational objective; Factor Xa inhibitors are having the specific action on Factor Xa with specific antithrombin activity. They can be used for increasing the PT and aPTT times. Here they will not be affecting the Thrombin time. Heparin can easily prolong TT.

questions.text: Richard and his son were walking towards their home after a cup of tea from outside. Near to his home he had an episode of fainting. And he was supported by his son to sit in a chair. Suddenly he lost his consciousness and woke up spontaneously after a minute. He was taken to an emergency department. The doctor ordered and electrocardiogram and it showed that the patient had a pulse rate of 49 bpm, regular rhythm and narrow QRS complex. There was desynchronization between P waves and QRS complex. Which of the following part inside the heart will be responsible for accelerating the ventricle?
questions.solution:
In myocardium electric impulses are generated by SA node. Depolarization start from apex to base and from endocardium to epicardium. Impulses comes to the ventricles through the conduction system. SA node can produce a heart rate of 60-100 bpm

On ECG the pacemaker location can be identified.

AV node produce a heart rate of 45-55 bpm. When there is an impairment between SA node and AV node, the AV nodal cells can act as the pacemaker cell.

This happens when AV block occurs. Here SA node causes atrial contraction while the impulses from AV node causes ventricular contraction. QRS complex will be narrow since ventricular depolarization goes in a normal way.

Option A, C : Heart rate will fall to almost 20 bpm as the electrical impulses are generated below bundle of His and AV node. In ECG we can see an abnormally shaped QRS complex since the impulses conducted through ventricles.

Option D : The heart rate will be normal electrical impulses are generated through SA node. In the ECG, P wave will be synchronized with QRS complex.

Educational objective : SA node is the main pacemaker of the heart because it has got the fastest firing rate. Only when the normal impulse conduction gets impaired, the other cells of the conduction system will come to act as the pacemakers.

questions.text:
Doctors of Washington University were having a study on membrane potential of human muscle cells. Many theses have been already submitted by the doctors. Now they are coming up with a study on animal. Due to ethics problem, neurophysiology doctors were about to conduct the experiment on a special animal called Giant squid. Experiments on frog was easily carried out and this was the first-time doctors going to make the practical on a Giant squid. Experiment was done and the doctors were able to plot a graph with the recordings of membrane potential with time.  
Membrane is mostly permeable to potassium ion and in which of the marked area will be having more permeability?
questions.solution:
The given graph explains the potential changes across the membranes along with the time. The changes such as depolarization, repolarization, hyperpolarization and resting potential are known as action potential. This occurs due to change in permeability to sodium and potassium ions. Stages of membrane potential are as follows;

Option A marked area will be the resting potential usually -70mV which is maintained by high resting membrane permeability to sodium. Potassium efflux need the non-gated voltage channels to make the transportation easy. The inner side of the membrane will be getting negative charged at the resting potential considering outer surface of the membrane.

Depolarization occurs during the opening of sodium channels with rapid inward movement of sodium ions as in Option E. This can lead to an increased positive charge inside the membrane. Maximum action potential happens when the membrane potential acquires a positive value approximately +35m as in Option A.

Repolarization, option C; Closure of sodium channel and simultaneous opening of potassium ions cause for the condition of repolarization. This can create a reduction in the permeability to sodium ions and a slight elevation in the permeability to potassium. Major factor causing for the returning of membrane potential back to resting potential is the outward movement of potassium ions. Hyperpolarization, as Option D, occurs because of the voltage gated potassium channel getting opened for a duration of short time after the repolarization got completed. Here the membrane potential will be less as compared to the normal resting potential and it will reach the equilibrium potential of potassium that is -85mV.

Educational objective; The rate of passive diffusion of molecules through the membrane is called the permeability of the membrane. Electric charge and the polarity are the main factors which are responsible for the permeability. Molar mass is also a factor responsible for the permeability.

questions.text: 50-year-old Mark and his wife Esther was working in a multinational company. For the past few weeks Mark was feeling of general tiredness. He was not having any previous history. He also started with daytime sleepness and fatigue in the day time. He was taken to a physician and her wife also added that he was having a loud snoring in his sleep. Also, sometimes Mark has a break in his breathing. The doctor ordered him for a chest x-ray and a spirometry test. The most likely diagnosis for the patient can be;
questions.solution:
This patient has got the symptoms for recurrent nocturnal upper airway obstruction and apnea which can further lead to the obstructive sleep apnea syndrome. Each nocturnal episode causes transient hypercapnia and hypoxemia. This can be caused by reduced ventilation in the patient with obstructive sleep apnea. This can also result in the reflexive systemic and pulmonary vasoconstriction. Sympathetic cardiac stimulation can also be caused due to this. Untreated sleep apnea can further lead to the right heart failure too.

Systemic hypertension can be gradually developed in more than 50% of the patients with the obstructive sleep apnea. It can be considered as the result of stimulation of chronic cardiovascular stimulation and the increased level of norepinephrine.

Since 70% of the patients with sleep apnea have a BMI of more than 30kg/m2. Obesity can also contribute for this relation between sleep apnea and systemic hypertension.

Option B, C, D : Acute asthma can be accelerated by various factors that affecting on the upper respiratory tracts. Mainly such as the allergen exposure or smoke inhalation or cold weather. Adolescents can be affected by the acquired bronchiectasis. Adults are also affected and will be mainly associated with infection impaired drainage or inadequate host defence. Laryngeal carcinoma can be associated with the smoking and also with the alcohol use. These all conditions are not associated with the obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: 45-year-old Tyson was a national weightlifter who has got many medals for Ghana. After getting selected for the world championship, Tyson moved to Russia for the world championship. There he was quarantined for a period of 15 days. After 15 days his covid test was negative and he also got all other regular check-ups. He got his blood pressure 140/80mmHg, PR was 101bpm. Blood counts was all in a normal range. The weight Tyson had to lift was 180kg (396lbs). His coach ensured that he was fit for the trials before the competition. During his first trials, he was able to hold the weight above his head for 5 to 6 seconds. But suddenly he drops the weight involuntarily. Which of the following may be responsible for this drop of weight from his hand in a sudden manner?
questions.solution:
Organs of golgi tendon are located in the junctions of the muscle and tendon. These are innervated by group 1b sensory axons. Golgi tendon organs are connected with extrafusal skeletal muscle fibres which are contracting. Its connected in a series way. Extrafusal muscle fibres are the muscle fibres which are innervated by alpha motor neurons and they contract and generate the tension and that will be allowing the movement of the skeletal muscles.

Inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord get in contact with the group 1b sensory axons which will be synapsing the alpha motor neurons which can innervate to the same muscle. For the maintenance of muscle tension golgi tendon circuit will be acting as a negative feedback system. Golgi tendon organs will stop the contractions of the muscle, when a muscle exerts too much force and that can cause for the sudden relaxation of muscles.

Option B and D; Pacinian corpuscles are mainly located in the subcutaneous tissues on the skin. They are also located on the mesentry, peritoneum and capsules in the joint. Pacinian cells are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and Ruffini’s cells are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors. Ruffini’s end organs are also present in skin, subcutaneous tissue. Sensations of touch, proprioception and vibratory sensations will be innervating by myelinated A beta fibres. Both pacinian and ruffini’s cells help to mediate this.

Option C; Muscle spindles are connected in parallel with extrafusal fibres in contrast golgi tendon organs will be connected in the series way. They will be innervated by group Ia and group II sensory axons. This will be very much sensitive on the change of length in muscle. Stretch reflexes are mediated by muscle spindles. In most of the neurological examinations myotatic reflux is being tested.

Educational objective; Feedback system used for monitoring and maintaining the muscle length is the muscle spindle system while the muscle force is maintained by golgi tendon system. GTOs will not be responsive to touch or proprioception but they will be sensitive to increase in muscle tension.

questions.text: A 25-years-old male was brought to emergency department in agitated state. On history taking, he informed that he is taking recreational drugs and he last took it intravenously 10 hours ago. He now complains of vomiting, chills and myalgia. His pupil size is larger than normal. RR= 30/min Temp=39 degree C What is the most probable cause of patient’s condition?

choices.text: The patient has overdose of opioid
Patient is showing symptoms of withdrawal syndrome
These are signs of toxicity of MPTP
The patient is taking barbiturates along with opioids

questions.solution:
Physical dependence is common with chronic use of opioids, which is revealed on abrupt discontinuation as a withdrawal syndrome. Patient can present with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, chills, gooseflesh, myalgia, mydriasis, diarrhea, agitation, anxiety, yawning and hostility. With morphine or heroin, these signs and symptoms can start within 6-10 hrs after last dose and the intensity depend on degree of physical dependence. As this patient took his last dose 10 hours ago, he is showing signs of withdrawal syndrome (agitation, chills, vomiting and myalgia). Administration of an opioid at this time suppresses abstinence signs and symptoms almost immediately

A) Manifestation of opioid overdosage are shallow breathing, flaccidity, cyanosis, pin point pupil, fall in BP and shock. This is not the case here in this patient

C) N-methyl-4-phenyl tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) occur as contaminant of some illicit drugs, produces nigrostriatal degeneration and manifestation similar to Parkinsonism. However, history is not suggestive of its use in this patient

D) Barbiturate poisoning is associated with CNS depression and cardiovascular collapse. But, nothing in history suggest their usage in this patient.

Learning objective: Abrupt discontinuation of opioids in a physically dependent patient can cause withdrawal/ abstinence syndrome

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with diabetes and hypertension for more than 10 years has been recently diagnose with diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following is the most characteristic finding in such patients with diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Diabetic Nephropathy Three lesions are encountered: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and Nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Capillary Basement Membrane Thickening. Widespread thickening of the glomerular capillary basement membrane (GBM) occurs in virtually all cases of diabetic nephropathy and is part and parcel of the diabetic microangiopathy Diffuse Mesangial Sclerosis. This lesion consists of diffuse increase in mesangial matrix. Nodular Glomerulosclerosis. This is also known as intercapillary glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease. It is the Most characteristic finding of Diabetic Nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 60-years-old female patient was diagnosed with hypertension and started on some anti-hypertensive medication. She is here for follow up and her serum electrolytes are as follows
Na+136 mEq/L
K+ 6.5 mmol/L
Which of the following medication she was started on?
questions.solution:
ACEIs (Enalapril) are one of the first-choice drugs for treating HTN. Mostly they are well tolerated. The side effects associated with ACEIs include cough, angioedema, hypotension, hyperkalemia (as seen in this case), skin rash, neutropenia, anemia and fetopathic syndrome

A) Calcium channel blockers (Amlodipine) are another class of first line antihypertensive drugs. They are involved in CYP3A4-mediated drug interactions, but have no effect on sodium and potassium levels

B) Loop diuretics (Torsemide) are indicated in presence of renal insufficiency, CHF, resistant cases or hypertensive emergency. They also cause hypokalemia and hyponatremia

C) Nebivolol’s role as first choice in the treatment of HTN debated. It has no effect on potassium level, it is rather associated with bradycardia, bronchospasm, peripheral vasoconstriction, worsening of acute heart failure (Nebivolol NO-mediated vasodilation)

Learning objective: while loop diuretics and thiazides cause hypokalemia, ACEIS/ARBs cause hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following are used in the management of hyperkalemia ?

Insulin + dextrose
IV Calcium carbonate
Potassium binding resins
Propanolol
Hemodialysis
Loop diuretics

choices.text: Options a , b , c, e, f

questions.solution:
Option b : IV Calcium gluconate is used

Option d : Salbutamol is used which is a beta agonist NOT Propanolol [beta blocker]

MANAGEMENT OF HYPERKALEMIA

Treatment modality Mechanism of action
IV Ca2+ gluconate Protects heart used if ECG changes are present
IV insulin + 50% dextrose (glucose helps to reduce risk of hypoglycemia)Salbutamol Redistribution of K+ to tissues
Loop diuretics Dialysis Excrete K+ out of body
K+ binding resins [ mainly for chronic hyperK+ ] Reduce K+ absorption from GIT

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and painful, stiff joints for one month. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice. Her vitals are within normal limits. Investigation findings include anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with increased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. The peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cold AIHA

  • This is the case of cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia (cold AIHA), in which the patient presents with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and arthralgia for one month.
  • Examination findings of pallor and jaundice, along with the presenting complaints, indicate an ongoing haemolytic disorder mediated by cold temperature.
  • This is further confirmed by anaemia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased reticulocyte count on laboratory findings.
  • Positive direct Coombs test for C3d and marked agglutination of RBCs seen in the above picture on peripheral blood smear confirms the diagnosis.
  • Cold AIHA is an autoantibody-mediated disorder characterised by the destruction of RBCs by cold-mediated autoantibodies at cold ambient temperatures of 0–4°C resulting in abnormal complement activation leading to acute intravascular and extravascular Haemolysis.
  • Clinical symptoms result from binding IgM to red cells in vascular beds where the temperature may fall below 30°C, such as in exposed fingers, toes, and ears.

Option B: Warm AIHA

  • It is also an autoantibody-mediated disease characterised by the binding of heat-sensitive autoantibodies, instead of cold-mediated antibodies, to RBCs, leading to increased red cell destruction by phagocytes and reticuloendothelial systems.
  • This autoantibody reaction is usually triggered by body temperatures of ≥ 37°C/98.6°F, with peripheral blood smear showing abundant spherocytes.

Option C: Hemoglobinopathy

  • It is usually characterised by the abnormal structure of haemoglobin, which can be seen on peripheral blood smears in the form of sickle-shaped or rod-shaped RBCs, target cells with microspherocytes.
  • It includes haemoglobin C disease, haemoglobin Zurich, sickle cell anaemia, and thalassemia.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited disease resulting in impaired glutathione regeneration, leading to increased susceptibility of RBCs to oxidative stress like infection, various drugs, and consumption of fava beans. This results in episodic hyperproliferative haemolytic anaemia.
  • Heinz bodies (small inclusions in RBCS containing precipitates of denatured haemoglobin) and bite cells are usually seen on peripheral blood smears.

questions.text:
Blood pressure (BP of Mr. Ram is 120/80 mm Hg). Four different sphygmomanometers (I, II, III, IV) are used to measure his BP with 3 readings each . Based on their respective accuracy and precision parameters.



Readings of sphygmomanometer
Parameters



A
B
C
D


120/80, 120/80, 120/80
140/80, 108/62, 96/82
140/96, 140/96, 140/96
122/82, 120/80, 118/78


I
II
III
IV


Precise but inaccurate
Imprecise but accurate
Precise and accurate
Imprecise and inaccurate

choices.text: A - II, B - IV, C – I, D – III
A – III, B – II, C – II, D – I
A – IV, B – III, C – II, D – I
A – III, B – IV, C – I, D – II

questions.solution:
• Accuracy: degree of closeness of a measured or calculated quantity to its actual (true) value
  • Precision: the degree to which further measurements or calculations show the same or similar results; Precision is also known as: reliability, repeatability, consistency or reproducibility
  • Reliability is precision, while validity is accuracy

questions.text: A 22-year-old male with history of chest pain and poolyarthrisitis was diagnosed with Acute Rheumatic Fever. Which of the following is the mechanism for development of ARF?

choices.text: Due to toxin secretion by streptococci

questions.solution: Acute rheumatic fever results from immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. pyogenes) which cross-reacts with host tissues. The antibodies directed against the M proteins of streptococci cross react with the self antigens in the heart. In addition, CD4+ T cells specific for streptococcal peptides also react with self proteins in the heart and produce macrophage activating cytokines. So, the damage to the heart tissue is a combination of antibody and T-cell mediated reactions.

questions.text: A 45 year old oil factory worker presents with abdominal pain and rectal bleeding for past two days ,also he complains that he is having , excessive fatigue and joint pain physical examination shows abdominal tenderness , cutaneous ulcers..on examination the blood pressure is 165/105 mm hg and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated . Antinuclear antibodies, antibodies to double stranded DNA and anti nuclear cytoplasmic antibodies are absent.Most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Poly Arthritis nodosa is rare disorder resulting from vasculitis or blood vessel inflammation multi organ systems are involved in PAN so it shows wide range of symptoms. Most commonly affects Nerves, intestinal tract, heart, joints kidney, medium sized vessel are affected by PAN. Etiology is unknown but reaserchers strongly supports that the autoimmune responses have a major role in PAN. signs and symptoms : fever, fatigue, decreased appitate and weight, myalgia, arthralgia, hard tender nodules/ulcers, abdominal pain, blood in stool, shortness of breath , chest pain and so on.

Choice A : Wegeners granulomatosis causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. anti nuclear cytoplasmic antibodies are present in Wegeners granulomatosis.

Choice B : Takayasu's arteritis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the largest blood vessel in the body, usually leads to damage to the aorta.

Choice D : Miller Fisher syndrome is a mild form of Guillain- Barré syndrome. It causes nerve damage, resulting in a loss of coordination, reflexes, and muscle control.

Educational objective Polyarteritis nodosa can be rapidly fatal or develop gradually.Biopsy of an affected organ or arteriography of the blood vessels can confirm the diagnosisPolyarteritis nodosa most often develops during middle age, usually when people are in their 50s, but it can occur at any age. It is rare.Polyarteritis nodosa can be mild at first but can worsen rapidly and be fatal within several months.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female was admitted with a complaint of escalating abdominal pain, increased abdominal circumference, and recurrent diarrhea for 2 months. He has a history of consumption of bush teas for 5 months to reduce weight. Physical examination revealed mild jaundice, distended abdomen, and tenderness on RUQ. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.82 × 109/L, Hb 122 g/L, HbsAg (-), ALT 66 U/L, AST 81 U/L, serum total bilirubin 39.7 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 10.6 μmol/L, and ALB 32.8 g/L. CT scan of the abdomen revealed moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, delayed enhancement of parenchyma, and obscure hepatic veins. Which of the following drugs is effective in improving survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Defibrotide

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of veno-occlusive disease.
  • Bush tea contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which is a risk factor for the development of veno-occlusive disease.
  • Treatment of choice: If hepatic failure is present – Liver transplantation.
  • If there is no hepatic failure – side-to-side portocaval shunt.
  • One drug is effective in improving survival – DEFIBROTIDE.

Option A. B, and C do not improve survival rate in veno-occlusove diseases.

questions.text: A patient, 22-year-old male is brought to the opd with consistently increasing stiffness in the back. The surgeon observes that over the last many visits to him the patients ‘Chin Brow angle’ has increased with every visit. What is the patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by consistently increasing stiffness in the spine due to fusion of the vertebrae. As the vertebrae fuse the patient acquires a posture of flexion and in severe cases the vision is limited to narrow area at the feet.

Learning Objectives: Certain appearances provide the clinician an opportunity to make a spot diagnosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of ball-rolling movements and projectile vomiting of undigested food particles. There is no history of allergy or drug abuse. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a positive succussion splash test. Endoscopy reveals a gastric mass obstructing the pylorus. A biopsy of the lesion revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following anemia is a risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pernicious anemia

  • It is an autoimmune disease due to the CD4+ cell-mediated immune response or antibodies against the stomach's parietal cells.
  • In pernicious anemia, there is progressive destruction of parietal cells, and it results in:
    • Decrease hydrochloric acid secretion, which increases gastric pH.
    • Decrease intrinsic factor secretion impairs vitamin B₁₂ absorption.

Option B: Megaloblastic anemia

  • It is a type of megaloblastic anemia that occurs due to vitamin B₁₂ or folate deficiency.
  • In this anemia, the bone marrow produces stem cells that produce enlarged red blood cells.
    • Fatigue
    • Pallor
    • Shortness of breath.
  • Vitamin B₁₂ deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
    • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Folate/vitamin B9 deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Decrease intake of green vegetables, fish, and meat.
    • Cohn’s or ulcerative colitis
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Increase alcohol intake.

Option C: Aplastic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia in which bone marrow does not produce new blood cells.
  • It is an autoimmune disease in which T-cell-mediated autoimmune destruction of bone marrow occurs.
  • It mostly occurs due to the following:
    • Chemotherapy
    • Toxins (benzene)
    • Certain drugs (like chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, and phenytoin)
    • Autoimmune disorder.
    • Parvovirus (short-lived)
  • It manifests the following:
    • Fatigue
    • Pale skin
    • Shortness of breath
    • Severe bruises
    • Increased risk of infection

Option D: Hemolytic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia that occurs due to the early breakdown of red blood cells.
  • Red blood cells have a 120-day life span; if its breakdown occurs, bone marrow has less time to form new RBCs.
  • There are many types of hemolytic anemia:
    • Sickle cell anemia
    • Thalassemia
    • G6PD deficiency
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Jaundice
    • Tachycardia
    • Dyspnea
    • Fatigue
    • Enlarged spleen or liver

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with repeated transient loss of consciousness lasting less than 10 minutes. After regaining consciousness, he experienced no disorientation, confusion, or tongue‐biting. He has been diagnosed with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy 3 years ago and is currently on maintenance with Sodium Valproate. Subsequently, an electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a 4-6 Hz polyspike pattern. Which of the following would be this patient's most common additional presentation?

choices.text: Generalized tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

questions.solution:
Option C: Myoclonus

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JANZ syndrome)

  • It is a common form of generalised epilepsy that occurs in otherwise healthy adolescents and presents with the triad of myoclonic jerks, generalised tonic‐clonic seizures, and absence seizures.
  • It is commonly characterised by bilateral myoclonic jerks that may be single or repetitive.
  • It has a Polygenetic inheritance and is strongly associated with a family history
  • Onset is usually 10 -19 years of age.
  • Clinical Features include: Sodium Valproate (lifelong)
    • Myoclonic Jerk (early morning) Prominent in the morning after awakening.
    • Consciousness is preserved unless severe.
    • EEG shows a 4-6 Hz Polyspike pattern.
    • May develop generalised tonic-clonic seizures; in the future, and 30% will also develop absence seizures in the future.
  • Provoking factors include:
    • Sleep deprivation
    • Alcohol withdrawal
  • Treatment:
    • Sodium Valproate (lifelong)

Option A: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures during sleep

  • It is a form of Primary generalised epilepsies that can be seen when a person is asleep.
  • These Seizures may be provoked by:
  • Sleep deprivation 
  • Fatigue, alcohol
  • Fever
  • Menstrual cycle
  • Flashing lights

Option B: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

  • It is the most common form of Primary generalised epilepsies.
  • Onset is 10–25 years of age.
  • EEG shows spikes and waves on waking and sleep onset.
  • It is provoked by Sleep deprivation.
  • Treatment includes sodium valproate.

Option D: Absence seizures

  • Absence seizures (petit mal) always start in childhood > 10 years.
  • They frequently occur (20–30 times a day) and are not associated with post-ictal confusion.
  • Seizures start and finish abruptly (unaware of absence)

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the ED by ambulance immediately after a road traffic accident. The patient in ICU receives an emergency blood transfusion as part of the resuscitation efforts. SpO2 is reduced to 75% at room air three hours later with sudden respiratory difficulty. CVP is 15cm water and PCWP is 16 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely associated with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Characterized by acute respiratory distress within 12 hrs of transfusion
Results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies
Leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that decrease capillary permeability
The implicated donors are frequently nulliparous women

questions.solution:
Option B: Results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies

  • The typical presentation of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension within 6hr of transfusion.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.
  • TRALI results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • Pathogenesis of TRALI is similar to ARDS
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability.
  • The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women, and transfusion of their plasma component should be avoided.
  • It can also present with fever (which develops within 6 hours after transfusion) and typically resolves within 48 to 96 hours. 

Option A: Characterized by acute respiratory distress within 12 hrs of transfusion

  • TRALI developes within 6 hours of transfusion and characterized acute respiratory distress.

Option C: Leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that decrease capillary permeability

  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that don't decrease but increase capillary permeability.

Option D: The implicated donors are frequently nulliparous women

  • Multiparous women are often implicated donors of blood transfusions, resulting in transfusion-related acute lung injury.

questions.text: A 19-year-old G4P3 at 23 weeks’ gestation presents with a rapid plasma reagin test (RPR) result of 1:8 .Confirmatory testing is positive. The patient has no signs or symptoms of syphilis. Two years ago, the patient’s RPRwas nonreactive. The treatment plan for this patient should be which of the following?

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, weekly for three doses
Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, weekly for two doses
Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM once
Aqueous procaine penicillin, 4 million units IV every 4 hours for 1 0 days

questions.solution:
Recommended Treatment for Pregnant Women with Syphilis 

Category  Treatment
Early syphilisa  Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection - some recommended a second dose 1 week later
More than 1 - year durationb Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses
Neurosyphilisc

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3-4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10-14 days

             or 

Aqueous procaine penicillin, 2-4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10-14 days

aPrimary, secondary, and latent syphilis of less than 1-year duration.

bLatent syphilis of unknown or more than 1-year duration, tertiary syphilis.

cSome recommend benzathine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly after completion of the neurosyphilis treatment regimens.

From the centers for disease control and prevention (2006b).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was diagnosed to have chronic hepatitis C. He responded to treatment with interferon. However, after one year of follow-up, he showed a relapse of the disease. Which of the following would be the next most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
• Retreatment is indicated for Relapser after a previous course of standard interferon monotherapy or combination standard interferon/ribavirin therapy.
  • A course of PEG IFN plus ribavirin (retreatment not recommended with PEG IFN/ribavirin if relapse occurred after a full course of PEG IFN/ribavirin).
  • Retreatment is also recommended for Non responders to a previous course of standard IFN mono-therapy or combination standard IFN/ribavirin therapy.
  • A course of PEG IFN plus ribavirin—more likely to achieve a sustained virologic response in white patients without previous ribavirin therapy, with low baseline HCV RNA levels, with a2-logl0 reduction in HCV RNA during previous therapy, with genotypes 2 and 3, and without reduction in ribavirin dose.(Retreatment not recommended with PEG IFN/ribavirin if non response occurred to a full course of PEG IFN/ribavirin).

questions.text: 30-year-old G4P2A1 Mary with gestational age of 13 weeks, healthy and has no previous history of diseases. During prenatal check-up, she was ordered for a blood sugar, lipid profile and an ultrasonography scan. She presented with an elevated temperature. Her vitals were checked, and blood pressure was 117/79mmHg. Prior to this check-up, she had only multivitamin tablets. This time she was also ordered for an antipyretic drug too. USG reports also came to be normal. The blood reports came to be Glucose -215mg/dL and triglycerides- 234mg/dL. Triglycerides is an agent which can gradually lead to myocardial infarction. Which of the following substance can likely promote to Mary’s abnormal laboratory results?
questions.solution:
METABOLIC EFFECTS OF HUMAN PLACENTAL LACTOGEN

Profound alterations in the maternal metabolism can cause for the pregnancy. Metabolism of carbohydrate can be connected toward the glucose and to the fetus, aminoacids can be shunted. Here the mother will be getting the excess fatty acids, ketones and glycerol. This can be done successfully via placental hormones. One of the examples is human placental lactogen.

Syncitiotrophoblast is secreting the human placental lactogen, which go a structurally similar to prolactin and growth hormone. Maternal insulin resistance can be increased by hPL. This is helpful in reducing the maternal glucose utilization and elevate the blood glucose level by which it will be allowing the glucose to be shunted towards the baby. HPL can promote for the breaking of proteins and lipids, which leads to the condition of energy demand of the mother made up by free fatty acids and ketone bodies. This can also lead, to make the glucose more free to reach for the fetal use. Ketones can also provide the fetus with energy, in case if the mother had a malnutrition.

Maternal insulin resistance can, not only be occured due to the increased secretion of hPL but also due to the growth hormone, estrogen, progesterone, glucocorticoids production from the placenta. When a women’s pancreatic function will not be sufficient to overcome the increase in insulin resistance which is related to pregnancy will be resulting for the gestational diabetes.

Option A : This is responsible for the secretion of milk and the contraction of uterus. Glucose and the lipid metabolism will not be affected by this.

Option C : HCG is a hormone which is secreted by placenta. It helps in the promotion of maintenance of corpus luteum. This happens in the early phase of pregnancy. And this will lead to the release of progesterone. Progesterone can help in maintaining the secretory endometrium.

Option D : Thyroid binding globulin can be increased in pregnancy. All the free thyroid hormones will be in the normal level. T3 and T4 which are the circulating ones will be increased.

Educational objective : hPL has the ability to increase the insulin resistance. Breaking down of proteins and lipids can also be stimulated by hPL. Human placental lactogen can inhibit the process of production of new glucose. Resistance to maternal insulin can also be resulted from placental growth hormone, estrogen, progesterone and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman (G2P1L1) with diabetes mellitus delivers a child after 38 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the most likely abnormality that might be encountered in this child at birth?
questions.solution:
• Tight glucose control in diabetic mother is necessary to prevent overstimulation of fetal pancreas during gestation.
  • Fetus exposed to hyperglycemia in utero may develop hyperplasia of pancreatic β-cells, → secrete insulin autonomously → hypoglycemia
  • Increased birth weight [macrosomia] is commonly encountered in offspring of diabetic mothers
  • The incidence of mental retardation is not specifically increased.

questions.text: An elderly multiparous women with intrauterine foetal death was admitted with strong labour pains. The patient suddenly goes in shock with cyanosis, respiratory disturbances and pulmonary oedema. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism

Diagnostic Criteria for Amnionic Fluid Embolism:

  • Abrupt onset of cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise. Documentation of overt disseminated intravascular coagulation.
  • Coagulopathy must be detected prior to loss of sufficient blood to cause dilutional or shock- related consumptive coagulopathy.
  • Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of placental delivery.
  • No fever ≥38°C.

Predisposing conditions

  • Rapid labor
  • Meconium stained fluid
  • Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins that permits exchange of fluids between maternal and fetal compartments
  • Labour induction or augmentation
  • Placental abruption

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labour ward. A 27-year-old female delivered a term baby boy by Normal Spontaneous Vaginal delivery with epiosiotomy performed. All of the following statements are true for episiotomies except:

choices.text: Can be either mid-line or medio -lateral
Involvement of anal sphincter is classified 3rd-4th degree perennial tear.
Mid-line episiotomies bleed less, are easier to repair and heal more quickly

questions.solution:
The birth canal is the path made by the pelvic curve through the planes of inlet mid pelvis and outlet, to be taken by the baby. An episiotomy will not increase the size.

Involvement of the anal spincter is called third degree tear and involvement of rectum is Type IV tear. Type III and IV constitute the Complete Perineal tear.

Midline epi bleeds lesser and heals better but can extend into anal sphincter easily. The lateral episiotomy is more inconvenient to the patient and bleeds more, but is more safer as far as tears are concerned

Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani are incised with an episiotomy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida is shifted or delivery in second stage of labour. Immediately after the delivery of the baby, the resident pulls the cord and along with the placenta, pulls the fundus of the uterus, out of the cervix. The senior obstetrician is called. What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning
Urgently take-up patient for Huntingtons surgery

questions.solution:
Uterine inversion usually occurs due to :

  • Fundal implantation of placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Cord traction applied before placental separation
  • Abnormally adhered placentation e.g. placenta accreta.

Manual Reposition under tocolytics such as terbutaline, MgSO4, can be done initially to reposition the uterus.

In most cases, manual reposition works.

If it fails, surgical interventions like haultain surgery and huntington procedure may be done.

questions.text: A 26 year old woman presents with infertility. She has regular cycles of 28 days with no dysmenorrhea. Her LMP was on 8th of May. When should her endometrial biopsy should be planned ?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

4.  29th May

Explanation:

To determine the optimal timing for an endometrial biopsy, it is essential to consider the menstrual cycle's phases and the endometrial changes that occur during the cycle. An endometrial biopsy is typically scheduled during the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, which is when the endometrium is at its thickest and most receptive state.

In a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, the phases typically occur as follows:

  • Follicular phase (pre-ovulatory phase): Days 1 to 14 (from the start of menstruation to ovulation).
  • Ovulation: Usually occurs around Day 14 (may vary depending on the individual's cycle length).
  • Luteal phase (post-ovulatory phase): Days 15 to 28 (from ovulation to the start of the next menstruation).

The secretory phase occurs during the latter half of the menstrual cycle (luteal phase) when the endometrium becomes thick and prepares for possible embryo implantation. It usually starts after ovulation and continues until the onset of the next menstrual period.

Given that the patient's last menstrual period (LMP) was on 8th May, and her cycles are regular, we can estimate the timing of her ovulation and the optimal timing for the endometrial biopsy as follows:

  • Ovulation (estimated): Around 14 days after the start of her cycle (28-day cycle), which is around 22nd May.
  • Secretory phase (estimated): From 22nd May until the next menstrual period.

Considering the secretory phase, the most appropriate time for the endometrial biopsy would be around 29th May (approximately a week after ovulation).

Option 1 (22nd May) would be around the time of ovulation, which is not ideal for the endometrial biopsy, as it should be performed during the secretory phase.

Option 2 (8th-12th May) includes the timeframe of the patient's menstrual period and the pre-ovulatory phase, which is not suitable for an endometrial biopsy.

Option 3 (Anytime during the cycle) is not the best choice because the ideal timing for an endometrial biopsy is during the secretory phase, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as the drug of choice for Chlamydia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
In non pregnant females – DOC for Chlamydia = Azithromycin

Treatment of Chlamydia infection during pregnancy

Regimen Drug and Dossage

Azithromycin is the first line treatment and has been found to be safe and efricacious in pregnancy .

Azithromycin is the best and the next best option is Amoxicillin (penicillin).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have anovulatory cycles. On the use of ovulation-inducing drugs, the follicle grows to a certain size but fails to ovulate. Before ovulation, the development of granules in the follicles is dependent on:-
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D:

  • The initial phase of follicular development before entering the menstrual cycle i.e. from primordial to Antral follicle is independent of gonadotropins. The early follicular phase is FSH-dependent. The late follicular phase is LH & FSH (both) dependent. Development of cortical granules in the follicle is dependent on LH, hence LH is required for its final maturation, before ovulation

Incorrect options:

Option A:

  • Estrogen is produced from the follicle and is responsible for endometrial proliferation

Option B:

  • Progesterone is produced from the corpus luteum after ovulation

Option C:

  • FSH mainly acts in the initial part of the menstrual cycle, and causes stimulation of follicles for growth

questions.text: A primigravida 36 yrs old in her second trimester of pregnancy comes to the clinic for her antenatal visit and was advised to undergo a triple test by her gynecologist. It is used for screening of Down syndrome in 2nd trimester. The test includes all the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Triple test:

  • Used for screening of Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • It includes:
    • AFP (α-fetoprotein)
    • β-HCG (β-human chorionic gonadotropin)
    • Unconjugated estriol
  • Detection rate is 67%

** Quadruple test:

  • Triple test + Inhibin A
  • It is also used as screening test for Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • Detection rate is 77%

questions.text: A 56-year-old lady presenting to OPD with postmenopausal bleeding for 3 months has a 1 x1cm nodule on the anterior lip of cervix. The most appropriate investigation to be done subsequently is
questions.solution:
Post menopausal bleeding with a visible cervical growth needs a tissue diagnosis, done by a punch biopsy of the lesion.

Paps smearis a screening test, done in asymptomatic patients.

Colposcopy + biopsyis a diagnostic test, indicated in symptomatic patients, like those with postmenopausal or post coital bleeding, or in asymptomatic patients where paps screening was done and turned out abnormal

Endocervical curettageis indicated in patients with suspected endocervical lesion, or if entire transformation zone could not be evaluated at colposcopy

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid female delivered a term baby boy following assisted vaginal delivery. Which of the following is the most common obstetrics nerve palsy in newborn?
questions.solution:
Brachial plexus and facial nerve injury are the more common types of birth injuries to newborn

Difficult delivery may lead to various obstetric palsies, most common being brachial plexus injury. Erb's paralysis (upper brachial plexus injury) and klumpke's paralysis (lower brachial plexus ) injuries are often described secondary to excessive shoulder traction during difficult labour.

Brachial plexus injury is 1-3 per 1000 deliveries

Facial is 0.2-7.5 of 1000 deliveries (mostly in uncomplicated deliveries and low forceps)

questions.text: A woman presents for the first antenatal visit at 30 weeks. Her sugars , 1 and 2 hours after a 75 gm glucose load are 190 and 188 mg/dL. Which amongst the following statements is true regarding management in this patient?

choices.text: Glyburide is absolutely contraindicated for management
She should be delivered between 34 and 36 weeks of gestation, as there is a risk of sudden IUFD at full term.
Presence of phosphatidyl glycerol in amniotic fluid is 100% confirmatory of lung maturity

questions.solution:
Normal values of OGTT are 92/180/153 (fasting/ 1 hour after 75gm glucose/ 2 hour after glucose load). This is thus a case of GDM with two vales deranged.

  • Unlike other oral hypoglycemic agents, glyburide and metformin both are being increasingly used for GDM (not for overt DM) and are found to be safe.
  • Patients with GDM/DM should be delivered between 38 and 39 weeks of gestation, as there is a risk of sudden IUFD at full term.
  • Hormones which do not cross the placenta are 1. Insulin, 2. PTH, and 3. Calcitonin.
  • Lung maturity is delayed in DM/GDM. L/S >2:1 is not the most reliable indicator. Phosphatidyl glycerol in amniotic fluid is 100% confirmatory of lung maturity in these cases.

questions.text: A patient who was using CuT for contraception, presented with a 20 weeks pregnancy. The IUCD is placed at the fundus, tail visible at OS and she wants to continue the pregnancy. What is your next step with this patient:
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

  1. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy

Explanation of each option:

  1. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy: In cases where a patient is found to have a pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place, and the pregnancy is desired to be continued, the best course of action is usually to leave the IUD in place and monitor the pregnancy. If the IUD is not causing any complications and the pregnancy is progressing normally, it can be safely left in-situ. However, close monitoring of the pregnancy and the IUD's position is essential throughout the pregnancy to ensure there are no issues or risks.

  2. Do medical termination of Pregnancy (MTP): Medical termination of pregnancy involves using medications to induce abortion and end the pregnancy. This option is not appropriate in this scenario since the patient wants to continue the pregnancy.

  3. Remove IUCD and continue pregnancy: In some cases, if the IUD is causing complications or is improperly positioned, it may be necessary to remove it. However, if the patient wants to continue the pregnancy and the IUD is not causing any problems, removing it is not mandatory. In many cases, it is safer to leave the IUD in place during the pregnancy, especially if it is embedded in the uterine wall.

  4. Remove IUCD and do MTP: This option involves both removing the IUCD and proceeding with a medical termination of pregnancy. However, since the patient wants to continue the pregnancy, this option is not appropriate.

questions.text: Which amongst the following statements is false about ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Medical therapy fails in at least 5–10% of cases
Alcoholism is a contraindication for methotrexate
Active intra-abdominal haemorrhage is a relative contraindication to medical management
Until the ectopic pregnancy is resolved, folic acid supplements—including prenatal vitamins—should not be taken

questions.solution:
Active intra-abdominal hemorrhage is an absolute contraindication to medical management. The size of the ectopic mass is also important. It is recommended that methotrexate should be avoided if the pregnancy is more than 4 cm, and fetal cardiac activity is present.  

According to ACOG contraindications for methotrexate include: breast feeding, alcoholism, immunodeficiency, liver or renal disease, blood dyscrasias, active pulmonary disease and peptic ulcer. Candidates for methotrexate therapy must be hemodynamically stable. They are instructed that:

  1. Medical therapy fails in at least 5–10% of cases. 
  2. If tubal rupture occurs (a 5–10% chance), emergency surgery is necessary.   
  3. If the woman is treated as an outpatient, rapid transportation must be reliably available. 
  4. Signs and symptoms of tubal rupture such as vaginal bleeding, abdominal and pleuritic pain, weakness, dizziness, or syncope must be reported promptly. 
  5. Until the ectopic pregnancy is resolved, sexual intercourse is prohibited, alcohol should be avoided, and folic acid supplements—including prenatal vitamins—should not be taken.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in labour ward. A 26-year-old term pregnant female is noted to have golden colour amniotic fluid. This can be seen in?
questions.solution:
Abnormal colour of amniotic fluid

Green – meconium stained (fetal distress conditions other than breech or transverse position).

Golden yellow – RH incompatibility. Greenish yellow (saffron) – post maturity.

Dark coloured – in concealed hemorrhage.

Dark brown (tobacco juice) – in case of IUD.

questions.text: A final-year medical student is attending a lecture on "Antenatal Radiological Evaluation" by the Gynecology department head. He is asked a question by the professor " By which week does the early diastolic notching of uterine artery disappears" Which of the following is the correct answer to this question?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 22 weeks

  • The early diastolic notch of the uterine artery doppler waveform analysis is assumed to be caused by significant blood flow resistance.

  • It has been linked to intrauterine growth restriction, pregnancy-induced hypertension, and worse perinatal outcomes.

  • Diastolic notching in uterine artery Doppler usually disappears beyond 22 weeks of gestation.

  • Persistence of uterine notch beyond 22 weeks is an indicator of pre-eclampsia.

​​​​​​​

Option A : 20 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

Option B: 21 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

Option D: 32 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2, LSCS 10 months back presents with history of irregular bleeding. HCG value is 66,700 mIu/mL. Ultrasound reveals a discrete central heterogenous with local invasion into myometrium, with normal ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of irregular bleeding after delivery with raised HCG and invasive mass on ultrasound is suggestive of persistent trophoblastic disease, most likely a choriocarcinoma (follows a nonmolar pregnancy)

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)

  1. Invasive mole: Develops after molar pregnancy only. Very rarely follows other gestations
  2. PSTT (Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor): may follow any type of gestation
  3. Choriocarcinoma: 2/3rd cases after normal delivery, 1/3rd cases after molar pregnancy
  4. Epitheloid Trophoblastic tumor: remote antecedant pregnancy

NOTE: After a nonmolar pregnancy, persistent GTN always has the histologic pattern of choriocarcinoma.

Histologic characterization of choriocarcinoma depends on sheets of anaplastic syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast without chorionic villi.

The choriocarcinoma is classically a soft, fleshy, yellow-white tumour with a marked tendency to form large pale areas of ischemic necrosis, foci of cystic softening, and extensive haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a complaint of hypermenorrhea for 3 months. Her ultrasonography scan reveals a 3.6-cm submucous uterine myoma protruding into the uterine cavity. Subsequently, she underwent a successful 2-hour hysteroscopic myomectomy. However, postoperatively she is experiencing headaches, vomiting, nausea, and lethargy, which is followed by seizures. What can be the most common cause of seizures in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyponatremia

  • Hyponatremia is the most common electrolyte abnormality in hospitalized patients, and values <120 mEq/dl lead to cerebral oedema and resultant seizures.
