  • Hyponatremia is strongly associated with seizures which are usually generalized tonic-clonic, but partial seizures may also occur.
  • Plasma Na+ concentration less than 135 mEq/L is a very common disorder in up to 22% of hospitalized patients.
  • This disorder is almost always the result of an increase in circulating Arginine vasopressin (AVP) and increased renal sensitivity to AVP, combined with an intake of free water; a notable exception is hyponatremia due to the low solute intake.

Option B: Hypernatremia

  • ECF concentration of Na is 142mEq/l, and ICF concentration is 14 mEq/l, so further rise or Hypernatremia will not affect resting membrane potential, and there are no seizures. 
  • Hypernatremia impairs neurons' plasticity and blocks the transmission of neurotransmitters.

Option C: Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia rarely causes symptoms in the CNS, and seizures do not occur.
  • Hypokalemia increases the resting membrane potential—i.e. hyperpolarization.
  • This results in membrane hyperpolarization and increased excitation.

Option D: Hyperkalemia

  • Hyperkalemia rarely causes symptoms in the CNS, and seizures do not occur.
  • Initially, potassium influx is higher as the cell is more permeable.
  • Potassium influx causes partial depolarization, so excitability Initially increases. 
  • During repolarization, Potassium cannot go outside due to loss in a concentration gradient, so overall excitability decreases, and thus, no seizures occur.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman G3P2 at 34 weeks of pregnancy has pain abdomen, uterine tenderness and bleeding per-vaginum. Her vitals are stable and has a regular fetal heart tracing. Which step of following is not required?
questions.solution:
• The above case history is suggestive of Placental abruption.

  • Route of termination should be decided depending upon maternal and fetal condition, bishops score and other obstetrical indications favouring a vaginal or cesarian delivery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P0, at 39 weeks of gestation, presents in active labor. On pelvic examination, the fetal head is placed in such a position that the occiput is placed anteriorly, and is fully flexed. Which of the following is the most common engaging diameter of the fetal head in such a position?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Suboccipito-bregmatic

  • This refers to the diameter between the suboccipital (back of the head) and bregma (anterior fontanelle). When the fetal head is fully flexed in an anterior position during labor, the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5cm) is often the most common engaging diameter.
  • This position allows for a more effective passage of the fetal head through the maternal pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Mento-vertical

Mentovertical diameter is 14 cm long and is engaged in brow presentation when the head is partially extended.

Option C: Sub-mentobregmatic

Sub-mentobregmatic diameter is 9.5 cm long and is engaged in a completely extended head presenting as a face.

Option D: Submento vertical

Submento vertical diameter is 11.5 cm long and is engaged in an incompletely extended head presenting as a face

questions.text: A T.V program wants to know how many people of the country are in favour of a particular political ideology. An announcement is made in the program and the viewers respond to the question through phone call or message. Which type of sampling method is this?
questions.solution:
• This is type of volunteer sampling.
  • The members of the sample self-select themselves for being the part of the study.
  • In other words it is not the investigator who approaches the participants rather participants themselves reach the investigator.
  • In this type of sampling the sample is restricted and non-representative of the country’s population in a way only those people are the respondents who were watching the program at that moment.
  • People who were busy in some other tasks could not take part. Moreover, the viewers are those who already have an interest in the ongoing topic.

questions.text: You are a medical officer organizing programme for creating awareness on coronary artery disease in the community. In a population to prevent the development of Coronary artery disease, changing harmful lifestyles by education is referred to as:-
questions.solution:
Primary level of prevention:

  • It is action taken prior to onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur.
  • It signifies ‘Intervention in the Pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease / health problem'.
  • Modes of Intervention:
  1. Health promotion : Targeted at strengthening the host through a variety of approaches / interventions, e.g. Environmental modifications, nutritional interventions etc.
  2. Specific protection : Targeted at prevention of a disease through specific prevention.[eg-vaccines]

questions.text: You are an intern posted in community health center. You are asked to present the Indian statistics regarding Road traffic accident deaths. All of the following statements are true regarding RTA deaths except:

choices.text: In India, the rate is 17/lac population
In India, there is no child restraint legislation
In India, the maximum permissible limit of Blood Alcohol Level is 80 mg/dl while driving
The death rate is higher in developing countries than in developed countries

questions.solution: In India, the rate of traffic accident deaths is at 17/lac population. Though, in India, we have rules regarding wearing seatbelt and helmet while driving, drunken driving, speed limits, use of mobile phone, there is no law on child restraint. In India, the maximum permissible limit of Blood Alcohol level is set at 30 mg/dl, as measured by Breath analyzer test. The death rate due to road traffic accidents is higher in low and middle-income countries.

questions.text: What is the correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality?

choices.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Prospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study> Case-control
RCT > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study > Cross-sectional > Case-control

questions.solution:
The correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality, from the strongest to the weakest, is generally as follows:

Option B. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

Explanation:

  1. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) - RCTs are considered the gold standard for establishing causality in epidemiological research. They involve randomization, which minimizes bias, and the controlled experimental design allows for strong causal inferences.

  2. Prospective Cohort Study - Prospective cohort studies follow a group of individuals over time to assess their exposure and outcomes. They are particularly useful for studying causal relationships because they can establish temporal relationships between exposure and outcome.

  3. Retrospective Cohort Study - Retrospective cohort studies also provide valuable data but may be subject to recall bias, making them slightly less robust for establishing causality than prospective cohort studies.

  4. Case-Control Study - Case-control studies are observational and compare individuals with a particular outcome (cases) to those without it (controls) to determine exposure differences. While they are useful for generating hypotheses, they are less strong for establishing causality due to issues like recall bias.

  5. Cross-Sectional Study - Cross-sectional studies provide a snapshot of a population at a single point in time. They are primarily descriptive and are generally weaker in establishing causality, as they do not capture temporal relationships between exposure and outcome.

The other options provided (A, C, D) do not represent the standard hierarchy of study designs for establishing causality, as they have a different sequence of study types or include ecological studies, which are typically used for generating hypotheses rather than establishing causality in individual-level relationships.

questions.text: Which of the following method of measuring maternal mortality obtain information by interviewing a representative sample of respondents about the survival of all their adult sisters (to determine the number of ever marrried sisters, how many are alive, how many are dead, and how many died during pregnancy, delivery, or within six weeks of pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Approaches for measuring maternal mortality ·

In the absence of complete and accurate civil registration systems, MMR estimates are based upon a variety of methods: 

  1. Civil registration systems : This approach involves routine registration of births and deaths. Ideally, maternal mortality statistics should be obtained through civil registration data.
  2. Household survey : Where civil registration data are not available, household survey provides an alternative.
  3. Sisterhood methods : Sisterhood methods obtain information by interviewing a representative sample of respondents about the survival of all their adult sisters (to determine the number of ever married sisters, how many are alive, how many are dead, and how many died during pregnancy, delivery, or within six weeks of pregnancy.
  4. Reproductive-age mortality studies (RAMOS): This approach involves identifying and investigating the causes of all deaths of women of reproductive age in a defined area/population by using multiple sources of data.
  5. Verbal autopsy: This approach is used to assign cause of death through interview with family or community members, where medical certification of cause of death is not available. Records of births and deaths are collected periodically among small populations, under demographicsurveillance systems maintained by the research institutions in developing countries.
  6. Census : A national census, with the addition of a limited number of questions, could produce estimates of maternal mortality; this approach eliminates sampling errors and hence allows a more detailed breakdown of the results, including time trends, geographic subdivisions and socialstrata

questions.text: A patient with complaints of high fever, runny nose, white spots inside the mouth, and skin rash, presented to the OPD. The clinical diagnosis of Measles was made by the physician. Which of the following age group is most commonly affected by measles?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: 6 months to 3 years

  • The age group most commonly affected by measles is 6 months to 3 years.
  • The clinical features of measles include 
    • Runny nose,

    • Skin rash
    •  High fever

Other options

Option A: 9 months to 3 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option B: 6 months to 2 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option C: 5-9 years 

  • Mumps is more frequent in this age group (5 to 9 years).
  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

questions.text: The perinatal mortality rate includes both late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths. Which of the following is the correct denominator to calculate perinatal mortality in a nation with less well-established vital records?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1000 live births

    • Because in the questions, the denominator for less well-established vital records nations is asked, answer A is the correct choice.

questions.text: The ratio between the incidence of disease among exposed and non-exposed is called:
questions.solution:
Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:

  • Relative risk (RR)
  • Attributable risk (AR)
  • Population attributable risk (PAR)

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/ Incidence among non-exposed

  • RR = Iexp / Inonexp
  • Interpretation of RR: Incidence of disease among exposed IS SO MANY TIME HIGHER as compared to that among non-exposed.

Attributable risk (AR) = Incidence among exposed- Incidence among non-exposed / Incidence among exposed.

questions.text: A physician, after examining a group of patients of a certain disease, classifies the condition of each one as ‘Normal’, ‘Mild’, ‘Moderate’ or ‘Severe’. Which one of the following is the scale of measurement that is being adopted for classification of the disease condition?

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the infectious ward in the department of internal medicine. You are seeing housekeeping staff disposing of the medical wastes without adequate protective equipment & are at risk of accidental needle stick injury. Which infections would cause the maximum chance of spread in accidental needle stick injury?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hepatitis B

  • Hepatitis B is spread when blood, semen, or other body fluids from a person infected with the virus enters the body of someone who is not infected.
  • This can happen through sexual contact, sharing needles, syringes, or other drug-injection equipment, or from mother to baby at birth.

Option B: HIV

  • HIV can be transmitted via the exchange of a variety of body fluids from infected people, such as blood, breast milk, semen and vaginal secretions. HIV can also be transmitted from a mother to her child during pregnancy and delivery.
  • But it has not had the maximum risk of transmission through needle stick injury.

Option C: Hepatitis C

  • The hepatitis C virus is usually spread when someone comes into contact with blood from an infected person. This can happen through
  • Sharing drug injection equipment.
  • Today, most people become infected with hepatitis C by sharing needles, syringes, or other equipment to prepare and inject drugs.

Option D: EBV

  • EBV spreads most commonly through bodily fluids, especially saliva.
  • However, EBV can also spread through blood and semen during sexual contact, transfusions, and organ transplantations.
  • EBV can be spread by using objects, such as a toothbrush or drinking glass, that an infected person recently used.

questions.text: A diagnostic test for a particular disease has a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.90. A single test is applied to each subject in the population in which the diseased population is 10%. What is the probability that a person positive to this test, has the disease?
questions.solution:
BAYES' THEORM

In the given question,

  • Sensitivity=0.90=90%
  • Specificity=0.90=90%
  • Prevalence=10%

PPV = (Sensitivity*Prevalence)/ [(Sensitivity*Prevalence)] + [(100-Specificty)(100 – Prevalence)] * 100

Thus, PPV=90*10/ [90*10] + [(100-90)(100-10)]*100 = 50%(0.50)

Number of person aged 15-65 per one older person aged > 65 and younger person < 15 years

questions.text: The number of live birth per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a year refers to?
questions.solution:
General Fertility Rate : Number of live birth per 1000 women in the Reproductive age group in a year.

Term Definition
Net reproduction rate Total No. of girl children born to a female, taking into account their mortality.
Gross reproduction rate Total no. of girl children born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span (15-44 or 49 years), assuming no mortality
Total marital fertility rate Total no. of children that would be born to a married woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span
Total fertility rate Total no.of children born to each woman if she were to live to the end of her child-bearing years and give birth to children in alignment with the prevailing age-specific fertility rates

questions.text: All the following are examples of Health promotion, except?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option C: Chemoprophylaxis

  • Primary prevention can be defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur".
  • It includes Health Promotion & Specific protection.
  • Chemoprophylaxis/vaccines fall under Specific protection.

Other options

Option A: Stop smoking

  • Decreased salt intake, stopping smoking, and installation of sanitary latrine comes under Health promotion.

Option B: Installation of sanitary latrine

  • Installation of sanitary latrines comes under Health promotion.

Option D: Decreased salt intake

questions.text: ‘Mobile eye clinics’ is an example for:-
questions.solution:
- Mobile eye clinics may conduct camps in villages where facilities are not much available.

- They conduct screening & diagnostic tests & gives treatment accordingly.

- As early diagnosis & treatment comes under 2nd level of prevention, answer is option-3.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal checkup, 20 pregnant women were questioned about their smoking history. After that, it was determined how many of them had low birth weight infants. What kind of study is it?
questions.solution:
Option B: Prospective cohort

  • Since the persons with exposure were followed to see the occurrence of the disease, this is an example of a Prospective Cohort.
  • This study design gives us incidence and RR which is very accurate.

Option A: Case-control

  • A case-control study is preferable for rare diseases.
  • In a case-control study, the selection of controls is a prerequisite.
  • Cases are diseased individuals; Controls are those free from the disease under study.
  • Controls must be similar to cases, as much as possible except for the absence of disease under study.
  • Strength of association in a case-control study: Case-Control studies cannot provide incidences, so the relative risk cannot be calculated.

Option C: Cross-sectional

  • It is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population at one point of time, results of the sample are then projected to the whole population.
  • It is the simplest form of observational epidemiological study.
  • Provides ‘Prevalence of the disease’ under study.

Option D: Ecological

 

  • Ecological Study (Correlational Study) is a type of analytical (observational) epidemiological study that provides the least satisfactory type of evidence on causality.
  • It is the least preferable observational/ analytical study design.
  • Units of study: Population

questions.text: In a study carried out prospectively, out of 1000 truck drivers who were using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. During the same period, out of 5000 truck drivers who were not using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. What is the Relative Risk?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 5

  • Exposure is mobile usage while driving, the incidence of accidents under consideration is that of:
  • Incidence of exposure (IE)= 300/1000
  • Incidence of non-exposed (INE) = 300/5000
  • RR (Relative Risk) = = 5 (thus mobile usage is associated with 5 times increased incidence of accident).
